div.p: THE WORthye Booke of Old age othervvyſe entituled the elder Cato, contayning a learned defence and praiſe of Age, and Aged men: writen in latine by that father of eloquence Marcus Tullius Cicero, and now engliſhed.
VVherunto is annexed a Recitall of diuerſe men that liued long.
With a declaracion of ſundrye ſoortes of yeares, and the diuerſitie betwene the yeres in the old time, and our yeares nowe adayes.
Imprinted at London by Thomas Marſhe.

div.head: To the Right high and Honourable Lord, VVillyam Paulet, of the noble order of the Garter Knyghte, Lorde S. Iohn, Earle of Wylſhyre, Marques of Wincheſter, and Lord Treaſurour of Englande.
div.p:
WHen as (ryght Honourable) I hadde fyniſhed this my rude tranſlation of Marcus Tullius Cicero his Booke of old age, begonne and ended by me this laſt yere hauing a quiet time of vacation among my frendes in Cheſshyre, therby to exclude and avoyde that lothſome and horrible Monſter Idleneſſe, whych holye Ambroſe aptlye calleth the Pillowe or Cuſsyon of Sathan, I called my wittes to counſayle and ſtudyed in my mind to whom my ſymple trauayle therein employed might beſte bee dedicated. Amonge all others, I could find none, vnto whome the whole proceſſe of
the matter, and the excellencye of the Argument ſeemed better to agre, then to your Lordſhippe. Vſing therefore the graue aduiſe of the famous Philoſopher and Chriſtian Ethnike (for ſo doubtethe not Eraſmus to cal him) Seneca, vvho vvilleth euery man that meaneth to beſtovve any gift or preſent vpon anye maner of perſon, not onelye to haue a diligent eye and reſpecte, that his ſayd gift be ſuch, as to his eſtate and degree is meete and agreeable, but alſo ſuch as to the dignitie and calling of the receauer is apt and conuenable: I humblye offer this litle Treatyſe of Olde age vnto youre honour, as vnto him, in vvhō Olde age to the great reioycing of al your vvelvvillers moſt triūphantly flouriſheth: truſting, yea rather not doubting, but that your L. vvil as fauourablye accepte it, as the noble king Artoxerxes (ſurnamed Memor) did a Pomegranate vvhiche one of his ſubiectes preſented him vvithal or as at an other time, hee did a lytle fayre riuer vvater, vvhyche a poore Perſian Peazaunte (ſeeinge manye people
thicke and threefolde to brynge revvardes to the kinge, and he hauinge nothinge, yet loth to come behinde vvith the ſignification of his poore loyal hearte tovvarde his Soueraigne) offerred vnto him in the holovvneſſe of his tvvo handes: or (to take an example neerer home, and of a Prynce of later dayes) as the politique and prudent Loys the eleuenthe of that name kinge of Fraunce, did a Radiſhe roote, preſented vnto hym by the handes of his poore vaſſall and Subiecte Conon the Burgonion. And becauſe beſyde a fruictful and learned diſcourſe of age, there be herein alſo enterlaced manye proper concluſions and feactes contryued in the prayſe and comendacion of Huſbandry, vvherin not onelye meane gentlemen and honourable Senatours, but alſo mighty monarches and puiſſaūt princes in old time toke great delight and pleaſure, together with a chronologie of diuers heroical and vvorthy enterpriſes, atchieued partly by martial provveſſe, partly by vviſe dō and pollicy: theſe al ſemed moſt fit to be
dedicated vnto youre excellencye, vvho is and of longe time hath bene the principall huſband of this famous Realme vnder our royall and ſoueraigne Princeſſe, and others her Graces noble Predeceſſours: vvho alſo moſt honourablye and faithfully haue ſerued her highnes and theym in their manifold and vvaightye affayres booth at home and in other forraine Realmes in great fauoure and eſtimation. VVhom God hath bleſſed vvith ſo proſperous a race of longe lyfe, to ſee the Children of your Childrens Children: ympes for their tovvardnes not lyke to degenerate from the vertue of their great Graundfather, neyther to forſake the ſteppes of their noble Graundfather. Here wil I vvade no farder, to ſpeake any thing, of the vertuous geftes incorporate in your noble breaſt, partly becauſe it mighte peraduenture ſeeme to ſmel of that vglie vice, vvhiche I dooe and euer haue deteſted, (I meane Adulation) and partly becauſe they ſufficiently cōmend themſelues to the eye of the vvorld, in ſo much that in reſpect of
them, my vvordes might be but as it vvere a candle lighted at high noone to helpe the ſhyning of the bright Sunne at midſomer. VVherfore in receyuing this vvorthy Senatoure and his ſmal traine, vvhom in this Dialogue he entroduceth reaſoning and talking one vvith an other of the cōmodities and diſcommodities of old age into youre patrocinie and protectiō (vvhoſe ſugred ſē tences and pregnaūt ſtyle, fraughted vvith a legion of vvitty perſvvaſions and eloquet argumentes, Penned by that incomparable Phenix of al eloquence among al that euer vvrate either before or ſince his dayes, I for lack of knovvledge haue racked from gorgeous Elegancie, and oute of Romayne govvnes more boldly I feare then vvyſelye chaunged into Englyſ he Liuerayes) you ſhal acquire and purchaſe great praiſe and glorie. Aſſuring your ſelf, that in defending and ſhrovvdinge thē againſt the poyſoned and ſlaunderous infamyes of ſerpentine Sicophantes, and the cancard aſſaultes of malicious tongues, vvhiche ſeede on no other
repaſt but ſpightful diſdaine and helliſhe rancoure, your L. ſhal do a thing (vnleſſe I be much deceyued) greatly ſounding to the generoſitie of youre noble hart and highe eſtate. For vvhat greater praiſe can there be then to be a patrone of vertue, and of them that are vertuous? Againe, vvherin is the honoure of the Honourable ſoe much blemiſhed, dymmed and Eclipſed, as in bolſte ring vice, and ſupporting the vvicked? Accept therfore (Right noble Lord this poore earneſt penye of my vnfayned good vvil into your tuition, vvherby I ſhal be anymated and encouraged hereafter perhappes to attempte ſome vvaightier matter.

In the meane ſeaſon, humblye and vvillingly ſubmittinge my ſelfe and al that I can do, to your Cenſure and commaundmente, I ſurceaſſe anye longer to trouble you. Beſeching God the Authoure and gyuer of al good thinges, ſo to infuſe his gracious giftes into you, that after the Epilogue and laſt Pageaunt of this mortal and tranſitorye lyfe (VVherin youre L. vvith
much vvorſhippe, more honour, and moſt authorytie theſe lxxxxvi. yeres hath ben a worthye and honourable Actor) you may be tranflated into the ioyes celeſtial, and be made partaker of his glorious kingdome Amen.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
IF I did not gentle Reader truſte more to thy frendly curteſie thenne to myne owne ſkill and iudgement, I would not with hazard of my fame haue enterpryſed the diuulgacion of this my ſimple trauaile to the gazinge view of euerye ſcrupulous and criticall beholder. But becauſe it pleaſed ſome to deſire me (who notwithſtanding had authoritie to comaunde me, to take this ſmall charge in hand. I am bold vpon their encouragemente and likinge to conceyue ſemblable hope of thy frendly and fauourable acceptaunce. Albeit long it was, ere I would willinglye relent to their requeſtes, pleadinge in excuſe of my vnablenes, and aledging
the incomparable ſublymity and ſappye eloquence of ye Authoure, wherby my Conſcience vpbrayded me of preſumption, in that, I hauing but a ſmal ſclender veſſel would aduenture into any ſuche ſea. Furthermore I was not ignoraunte howe this ſame was tranſlated about xxx yeares agone: but of al doubtes, this was the leaſte, for as much as that tranſlation beareth but the countenaunce of one, being none in dede to any purpoſe, being taken of the learned for noone at all, ſithens neuer a page almoſt is anſwerable to the latine textè, I wil not ſay, ſcātly any ſentence. Take therfore wel in worth my good, wil and aford me gentle report for my laboure which is the ſole guerdon that I do expect at thy hāds, and thinke not that the tranſlatours vnſkilfulnes
doth any thing derogate from the Authours worthynes, waigh my intente in the Balance of frendeſhippe and indifferencye, who to counteruaile the wante of power, am ſtored wïth as muche good wil as the beſt to pleaſure the.

div.head: The Preſace of the Authour vnto Titus pomponius Atticus.

q.l: O Tytus, if I eaſe thee of that paine,
And heauie charg vvhich doth the ſore annoy,
And makes thine hart ful penſiue to remain,
Shal I herein my laboure vvell employe?

div.p:
For in ſpeaking vnto the (friend Atticus) I maye vſe the ſame verſes and woordes, whiche that auncient and worthie Potte, more fully fraughted vvith honeſtye, and faithful dealing, than vvith vvorldly pelfe and rycheſſe, vſeth, in coumforting the noble Flaminius: albeit I am vvell aſſured, that thou art not ſo diſquieted night and day, vvith penſiuenes, care, and ſorovve, as Flaminius vvas: for I knovve thy paeiente ſufferaunce of all chaunces and bruntes of Fortune, and the vvell ſtayed moderation of thy mynde. And I do ryghte vvell vnderſtande hovve that thou haſte broughte hoome vvythe thee frome Athens, not onelye thy Surrename, to bee
called Atticus, but alſo gentle behauioure, courteſie, and prudence. Yet canne I not othervvyſe thynke, but that, novve and then aſvvel as I, thou arte ſore vexed and troubled in minde, for the tyrannous oppreſſions and greuous enormities novv in our common vvealthe perpetrated and comitted. The conſolation vvherof is ſo great, that it can not in this litle booke be fully declared, and therfore I vvil defer it, vntill an other time more conuenient. At this preſēt time, I thought it beſt to vvrit ſom litle Treatiſe vnto the, cōcerning Old age: becauſe I vvould faine haue both thee and my ſelfe, to be eaſed of this heauie burthen, which is commune and indifferēt to me aſvvell as to thee, (I meane Olde age,) vvhich novve already is either come vpon vs, or els ere it be longe, (we maye be aſſured) will catche holde on vs. Notwithſtanding, I know well that thou doeſt and wilt take the ſame modeſtlye, and as it becommeth a wiſe man to do, pacientlye, euen as thou arte in all other thynges accuſtomed.

But vvhenne as I purpoſed vvythe my ſelfe to vvrite ſomevvhat in prayſe and commendacion of Olde age, I deemed and
iudged the moſt vvorthy, vnto vvhom my laboure and ſtudie in this behalfe myght be dedicated, vvhiche boothe of vs, mighte ioyntlie and commonly vſe for our coumforte and contentacion. As for my part, I promiſe thee, I toke ſuch ſinguler pleaſure and delectacion in the compilinge of this Booke, that it did not onelye vtterlie take avvaie al the encombraunces and diſcommodities of mine Olde age from mee: but rather made the ſame vnto me pleaſaunt, ioyfull, and delectable. Therefore Philoſophie canne neuer be ſufficientlye praiſed, ſo muche as the vvorthineſſe and dignitie thereof requireth: vvhoſe preceptes and rules vvho ſo euer obayeth, maye paſſe the vvhole time of his age, and runne the full race of this life, vvithoute anye yrkeſome griefe or trouble. VVhat other vtilities and commodities it bringeth, I haue alreadie in manye other of my Bookes at large declared and meane hereafter manie times and often therof to make ample diſcourſe and mencion. But this Booke of Old age, I haue ſent vnto thee: vvherein the preminence and ſuperioritie of the diſputacion is not geeuen to olde Tithonus as Ariſto
Chius did in his Booke, leaſt in ſuche a fained fable the vvhole diſcourſe ſhould bee the leſſe eſteemed among the Readers: but I attribute the chyefe dignytie of it vnto the Old grayheaded ſage Marcus Cato, to thende the Treatiſe ſhoulde haue moore eſtimation credite and authoritie. And I introduce as ſpeakers, Laelius and Scipio, frankly and familierlie talking vvith him, and muche meruailinge to ſee him, ſo pacientlie and eaſelie to tolerate his old age, and vvhat aunſvveares hee made to theim again. VVhom if thou thinke more learnedlye heare to diſpute, then in his ovvne vvoorkes he vvas accuſtomed, impute the cauſe to his ſkilfulnes in the Greeke tongue, vvhereof it is vvell knovven that in his Olde age he vvas very ſtudious. But to vvhat purpoſe ſhould vve make any further preamble? for al that vve haue to ſay concerning Olde age, the talke and diſputacion of Cato himſelfe ſhall manifeſtlye declare.

sp.speaker: Scipio.
sp.p: OF tentymes boothe I and my freinde Caius Laelius alſo, are wont greatly to haue in an admiracion & to meruayle at the excellent and abſolute wiſedome O Cato, which thou vſeſt in all other matters and exploites what ſo euer thou takeſt in hand: but namely and ſpecially, bicauſe we neuer yet perceiued thyne old age to be burthenous and gréeuous vnto thée, whiche to the moſt parte of old men is ſo odious and vnwelcome, that they wil ſay they carie aboute with theym a burthen heautour then the great flaming Mountaine Aetna.

A verie ſlight and eaſie matter it is (deare frends Scipio and Laelius) which you do ſéeme ſo muche to muſe and meruaile at: for they that haue no power, pith of witte helpe, waye nor vertue in them ſelues, to conducte and bring theym to a good and bleſſed life, vnto ſuche as theſe bée, all their age is comberſome and vnpleaſaunt. But vnto ſuch, as leade their lyues vertuouſlye, meaſurynge all their actions by the ſquyre of reaſon, and haue their minds with al good giftes of grace beautified and garniſhed, ther is nothing thought ne déemed euil, that commeth by neceſſitie of nature. Of the which ſorte, Olde age is principally to be conſidered, vnto which all men wiſhe to arriue, and yet when they haue their deſire, they accuſe it, as painfull, ſicklie, vnpleaſaunte and tedious, ſuche is the braineleſſe vnconſtancie, fooliſhe ſottage and peruerſe ouerth wartnes of waywarde people.

They ſaye, it crepeth and ſtealeth vppon them, faſter and ſoner then they thought
it woulde. Fyrſt, who cauſeth theym to ymagine and thinke ſuch a falſe and peuiſh vntruth? for why ſhould they thinke that after their youthe and adoleſcencie, Old age créepeth faſter vpon theym, rather then their adoleſcencie and youthe doth after childhode? Seing therfore they do not repine nor complaine any whitte, after that they haue ben children, to grow to be tall Striplinges and luſtie youngemen, why ſhoulde they be aggreued or thinke theym ſelues diſcontented, after they haue bene Striplinges and younge men, to bée Old and aged? Againe, if they might reach to the age of eight hundreth yeres, what greater pleaſure and cōmoditie is therein, or wherein ſhoulde they thinke it to be leſſe trouble ſome, and tedious, then it is when they bee of thage of foure ſcore yeares? for the age that is once paſſed & gone, be it neuer ſo longe, can with no maner of pleaſure or delectacion, comfort, recreat, nor mytigate, the old age that is in ſuch fonde perſons. And
therefore if you bée wonte to wonder at me, and to haue my wiſedome in admiration (which I would to god were correſpondent to your good opinion conceyued of mee, and alſo anſwerable to my Surname) we are in this onelye poincte wyſe, becauſe we folow nature as a god, and takinge her as a ſure and infallible guide, direct and leauel al our actions according to her preſcript lawes and ordinaunces. Of whom, when all the other partes of age are well deſcribed and apoincted, it is not like to be true, that the laſt acte of al ſhold be negligently plaied & as it wer of an vnſkilful and dreaming Poete, loyteringly handeled. But in age there muſt néedes bee ſome extreme and laſt end, bending downe, drowping, and declyning from the luſtines and nymble actiuitie that was in flouriſhing youth, as it hapeneth & is plainly to be ſéene in the bearies of trées and other fruicts of the earth, when they be com to their due ripenes & natural maturitie: which euery
wiſe man wil paciently & willingly tolerate. For what other thing is ment, by ye temerarious & proud attempt of the Giants, warring & obſtinately fighting with the gods, but to reſiſt & go againſt nature?

sp.speaker: Laelius.
sp.p: But you ſhal do a ſinguler great pleaſure vnto vs both (for I dare vndertake for Scipio & ſpeake for him in thys poinct aſwell as for my ſelfe) to geue vs ſome fruictfull premonition wherby we may aforehand be inſtructed and alſo armed (becauſe bothe deſire & hope to lyue til we be old men) by what meanes wée may moſt eaſelie ſuffer & beare out oure old croked age, when it cometh.

sp.speaker: Cato.
sp.p: I wil (Laelie) fulfil your requeſt & willingly relēt to your peticiō, & eſpecially if I ſhal therby do ſuch pleaſure vnto both of you, as you ſay I ſhal.

sp.speaker: Scip.
sp.p:
Right glad wold we be, if it might pleaſe you, & be not to much paines & trouble for you O Cato, ſithe you haue as it were runne a great race, and gone a longe iourneye, (which path alſo we muſt tread) to heare
and vnderſtand what kynd of thing that is, whereunto you are alreadie arryued.

sp.speaker: Cato.
sp.p:
I will doe herein O Laelie what I am able: for I haue oftentimes bene in companye amonge my equalles and famyliers (for, like with like, accordinge to the old prouerbe, wil kepe company and beſt agre together) who haue greatly bewailed the diſcōmoditie of their old yeares, & thought them ſelues in an ill caſe by reaſon of their age, and namely Caius Salinator and Spurius Albinus, men that haue ben Conſuls, & in maner of ye ſame age ye I my ſelfe am, were wont greatly to murmure and repyne, ſorowinge and lamentinge for their old age: not onelye becauſe they thoughte theym ſelues to lacke pleaſures and laſciuious paſtimes, and to be vtterlye bereft & debarred from al ioyes and ſolaces, without whom they accompted their life to bee as no life, but alſo becauſe they were contemned and deſpyſed of thoſe, of whome they were wonte to be honoured, and reuerenced.
But in my opiniō, they blamed not that, whiche was blame worthye. For if the cauſe and blame therof, wer to be imputed to old age, then ſhoulde the ſame diſcommodities, coraſies and gréeuaunces happen vnto me and al other old men, of whom I haue knowen a great maignie, that haue liued in their olde age without any whyning, complaint, or diſcontentacion: who were well pleaſed to be vngiued, looſed and deliuered out of the yoke of their ſenſuall luſtes and voluptuous appetites, who alſo were neuer deſpyſed of their friends and acquaintaunce. But the blame & fault of al this mutteringe & cōpleyning is in the ouerth wartenes of mens wayward maners and not in age. For diſcrete, ſober, and temperate olde men, being neither ill to pleaſe, froward nor churliſhe, do liue in their old age tolerably and quietly ynough, both to them ſelues and al others. But vnbrideled inſolencie, and blunt vncurteſie, is to al age vnpleaſaunt, tedious & yrkſome.

sp.speaker: Laelius.
sp.p: It is euen ſo, as you ſay Cato, but there wil ſome peraduenture ſaye vnto you, ye your olde age, ſéemeth to you tolerable ynough, becauſe of your great wealthe, rycheſſe and dignitie, but ther be a great numbre of others, whiche can not haue ſuch ample poſſeſſions nor ſuch extra ordinarie helpes to alleuiate and condulcate ye aſperitie and vnpleaſauntenes of their decrepite age.

sp.speaker: Cato.
sp.p:
In déede Laelie that whereof you haue nowe talked is ſomewhat, but all thinges do not reſt nor conſiſt in them: wherunto agréeth the quick and nipping ſentence of Themiſtocles, vnto whome, when as a certain raſcal peaſaunt of the Iſle of Scriphos tauntingly & ſpightfully ſaid, that he had not gotten ſo great fame and renowne of hym ſelfe, but rather through the noble and glorious celebritie of his flouriſhinge countrie: Thou ſayeſt truthe (ſaid he) for if I had bene a Scriphian berne, I ſhould neuer haue ben enuobled nor my name by ſo manye triumphant
victories blaſed abroad & eternized, neither if thou were an Athenian borne, thou ſhouldeſt neuer aſpire to any honorable dignity. In like maner may it be ſaid of oldage, for in extreme penurie, ſcarcitie & indigence it can not be eaſilye abyden, born, & tolerated, no not of a wiſe mā: neither it cannot be but cumbreſome & greuous to him that is a foole, although he haue neuer ſo great plenty, & abūdāce of althings. The very méeteſt weapons & fitteſt inſtrumēts for old age (O Scipio & Laelie) are ye perfect knowledge & the actiue exerciſes of vertue, whiche when it hath bene practiſed all the time of mans age, which hath liued a long time, dothe bring & yeld at length meruelous fruict & cōmodity, not only becauſe it neuer ſhrin keth nor ſtarteth frō vs, nor yet forſaketh vs, no not in the verie laſt poinct of age (which truly is an excellēt thing) but alſo becauſe ye cōſciēce of our former life which we haue led vertuouſlye, & ye remēbraūce of many good & pitiful dedes before tyme
and of ſundrye noble actes valiantlye atchieued is verie pleaſaunt, comfortable, and delectable vnto vs. Certes, I when I was a yong ſtripling did ſo loue Quintus Maximus, (the ſame was he that recouered the Citie of Tarentine) beynge then an old man, as though he had bene myne equall and of like age as I was.
For in that noble and prudent man, ther was to bee ſéene a kinde of ſeueritie and magnificence mingled & powdred with clemencie and a mercifull generoſitie.

His old age neuer altered nor chaunged his wonted maners, albeit when I firſt began to honoure and reuerence him, for the vertuous magnanymitie whiche I eſpied to raigne in him, he was not very old, but yet he was wel ſtriken in yeres. For I was borne one yeare after he had bene the firſte time Conſull, and in his fourthe Couſulate, I being a yong man, was a Souldioure vnder hym in his expedition to Capua, the fift yere after that, I was made Treaſurour and general receiuor
at Tarentine, then was I created Aedilis, and within foure yeres after, I was elected Praetor, whych office I bare and executed when Tuditanus and Cethegus were Conſuls. At that time he being a verie aged man, in publique audience counſailed the Senate & people of Rome to reuiue the Lawe called Lex Cincia, & to haue it to ſtand in effect & to be duelie executed. And being a man farre growen in yeres, he warred in the quarrel of hys Countrie, and to repulſe forraine hoſcilitie, was choſen Chieuetaine and Generall of the warres, wherin he ſo manfullye acquited himſelfe with proweſſes and pollicie, and was ſo couragious and laborious, as though he had ben a luſtie yonge Gallaunt in his floriſhing & freſh yeres, yea & with his lingering pacience & procraſtinacion, repreſſed and cooled the furious attemptes and outragious inuaſions of haultye Hanniball. In whoſe prayſe and commendacion, Enninus wryteth theſe verſes following.

q.l: One man by protracting the time vvith delay.
Hath ſaued our vveale publique and reſtorde it again.
For he neuer forced, vvhat poyſoned tongues did ſay
So that his countrie in ſafetie might remaine.
Therefore his great glorie, and illuſtrious name,
Is regiſtred perpetuallie vvithin the booke of Fame.

sp.p:
What vigilancie & what wiſedome vſed he, when Tarentine was delyuered to hym? I my ſelfe at that ſame tyme, when Salinator (who had loſte the towne and was ſledde into the caſtle) made his auaunt and proudly ſayd to Fabius theſe words. By my meanes it is come to paſſe: and me onely mayſt thou thanke O Fabius, for the recouerie and regaining of Tarentine, hearde him whenne he ſmyled and made this aunſwere to him againe: It is euen true that thou ſayſte (quod hee) for if thou hadſt not loſte the Towne, I ſhold not haue recouered and wonne it. And vnto theſe his valiaunt exploites & hardye actes in Martiall affaires moſte honourablie by warlicke proweſſe & vndaunted courage, atchieued his graue aduiſe and wiſe counſaile in tyme of peace concerning ciuile ordinaunces and politique
regiment, was in al poinctes correſpondent, for when he was the ſecond time created Conſull, and his felowe in office Spurius Caruilius not intermedling with ſuch waightye buſines as to his office were incūbent, neyther doing anye thing for the behoufe & honor of the common wealthe, yet hee remembringe hys charge & function reſiſted and with ſtode Caius Flaminius the plebeian tribune, to the vttermoſt of his power, who had contrary to the authoritie of the Senate preſumed & taken vpon him, to diſtribute & deuyde to euery one, man by man, al that piece of Italie that is called Picenum, and alſo that part of Fraunce that lyeth from the mountaines called Alpes to the riuer Rubicon. Alſo when he was Augur, hée wold not ſticke to ſay, that al ſuch things were fortunatly & with good luck enterpriſed & taken in hād, which tended to ye profite and behoufe of the comon wealth: & cōtrariwiſe, thoſe things ye were preiudicially attēpted to endamage or blemiſh
the ſoueraigne dignitie therof, were vnluckely & in an ill time incepted. Many & ſundry notable qualities haue I knowē to be incorporate in this noble ſage, but none more to be marueiled at, then how worthely & paciētly he toke ye death of his ſonne Marcus, who was a mā greatly for his deſerts renowmed & had ben Conſul In whoſe praiſe and commendacion hée hath wryten a funerall Oracion, ryghte pithie and learned, which when we read, wée are ſo rauiſhed with the elegancie & concinne vehemencie therof, that we cā not but ſay, that he ſurmounteth righte famous Oratours. Yea what Philoſopher do we thinke able to cōpare & match wyth him? And his noblenes was not ſo much and ſo greatly blazed abrode in the open ſighte and hearinge of men, but his inculpable behauioure and vertuous dealinge was farre greater, and muche more to bée extolled, whiche he vſed priuatlye when he was at home and in hys owne houſe. What profounde talke vſed
hée? what ſappie ſentences vttered hée? what wholeſome preceptes and rules to lead our life by, ſhewed hée? how expert and conning was he in the monuments of Antiquitie? how exactlie was he ſéene in the art of diuinacion? yea: knowledge and ſkilfulnes was in him (as in a ſtudious Romaine) great, exquiſite, and manifold. He perfectly remembred and by hart coulde recoumpte all the warres and exploites as wel ciuill and domeſticall, as forraine and external. Whoſe talke and conference ſo greatly delighted my gredie and thirſtie minde, as thoughe I had alreadie cōiected & deuined by an inward preſage, that which afterward chaunced, that when he dyed, I ſhoulde haue none nor fynd none, to reſorte vnto, for counſaile & learnyng. But to what end do I ſpeake ſomuch of Maximus? Trulie becauſe therby you may ſe, how ye it is agret villainy, to ſay that ſuch an old age as his was, is wretched and miſerable. But all men can not bee Scipiones nor Maximi,
to abuccinate and recompt what Cityes they haue ſacked, raſed and expugnated, to proclaime and tell abroad their Martiall conflicktes both by Sea and land, their warres victoriouſlye maintayned, their enterprices fortunately atchieued, nor their royal triumphes gloriouſly ſolemnyzed. For when a man hath ledde his former life, quietly, vprightly, godly & laudably, his old age is eaſie, myld, pleaſaunt and curteous, ſuch as the old age of Plato was, Plato died as hee ſatte writing. who in the .lxxxi. yeare of his age, died as he ſat wryting. And ſuch was the old age of Iſocrates, who is ſaid, that he wrate his worke entituled Panathenaicus, in the nynetye & fourth yere of hys age, & lyued fyue yeres after: whoſe Scholemayſter Leontinus Gorgias, liued fullye a hundreth and ſeuen yeares, and neuer faynted, drowped, nor gaue ouer his ſtudye and laboure whiche he had in hand. And when it was demaunded of him, why he would wiſh to liue ſo long: I haue (ſaid he) no cauſe whereby to accuſe
or miſlike mine old age. Anotable anſwere and worthy to procéede oute of the mouth of a famous and learned man. For doltiſhe ſottes, and béetleheaded fooles do lay al their owne faults and blame vpon old age: which the prudente Poete Ennius, (of whom we lately made mention, and whom you may wel remembre) vſed not to do. For he compareth his old age to the old age of a couragious Courſer or victorious horſe in theſe wordes:
Euen as a horſe of courage ſtoute
with comely porte and grace
VVhich oft hath born the bell, and vvone
The price in open race:
VVhen old age once with trembling pace
Hath him at length poſſeſt,
He ceaſſeth from ſuch frolicke feactes
And geeues him ſelfe to reſt.

This Ennius I dare ſaye, you doe remembre well, For theſe twaine, T. Flaminius & M. Attilius were created Conſuls the nynetenthe yere after his death,
and he died when Caepio and Philip wer the ſecond time Conſuls, being lxx. yeres old (for ſo long did he liue) at which time I being lxv. yeres old, with al my might and maine, and wyth an audible, & firme voice, exhorted the people, that the Law called Lex Voconia might bée adiudged good, and effectuall and by Autenticke authorytie irreuocablie eſtabliſhed.

Thus Ennius ſuſtayned and caried two ſuche burdens as are vulgarelie taken & ſuppoſed to be the greateſt that can bée, that is to witte, Pouertie and Old age, yea and in ſuch ſorte, that he ſéemed in a maner to be highlie pleaſed, and therin to take great obiectiō. For in pōdering & debating in my mind, I find that ther be foure principal cauſes, why Old age ſéemeth wretched and miſerable. One is, becauſe therby a man is impeached and hindered from taking in hand any fūction or charge in the comon wealth: an other is, becauſe it enféebleth & weakneth ye body, the third is, becauſe it doth almoſt
take away al pleaſure & laſciuious voluptée, & the fourth is, becauſe it is not far of from death. Now iet vs (if you pleaſe) ſift & diſcuſſe the force and validite of euerye one of theſe cauſes, and ſée how iuſt the allegacions of euerie of theym are. It hindreth and draweth a man backe, that he cannot do his affaires and buſineſſe, & from the adminiſtracion of diuerſe offices from what buſineſſe and offices? frō ſuch as are by luſtines of youth & bodily ſtrength atchieued? Are there no things appertainig to old men, which although their bodies be weak and féeble, yet may by the vigoure of the mind, be done & adminiſtred? Did Q. Fabius nothing? Did L. Paulus, who was thy father Scipio, & the father in law of that worſhipful man my Sonne, nothing? And a great ſort of old men moe. The Fabritij, the Curij, the Coruncani, whē they maintained & defended the weale publique with their graue coū ſailes & authorities, did they nothing? Appiꝰ Claudiꝰ was not only old & croked, but
blind alſo: yet when ye Senate wyth one accord, purpoſed to conclude a peace, and to condiſcende to a league with Pyrrhus, he was not afraide to ſpeake thoſe wordes which Ennius in his verſes recited.

q.l: VVhy do your wittes,
and ſenſes ſo raue?
VVhat fooliſhe conceipte,
doth encombre your braine?
VVhere bee the rype iudgementes,
vvhiche vvonte you vvere to haue?
To agree to your Countries,
ruyne moſt plaine?

sp.p: And muche more purſueth hee in his Poeme, concerninge the ſame matter, whyche you knowe well ynoughe: And yet the Oracion which Appius made, is to be ſéene, whiche hee made ſeuentine yeares after his ſecond Conſulſhip, and betwene his two Conſulates ther were tenne yeres, and he had borne the office of Tenſor before his firſte Conſulate.

Whereby it may be well perceyued & gathered,
that whē Pyrrhus inferred warre vpon the Romaines, he was a very aged man, and ſo haue we hearde our fathers and Progenitours reporte. Therefore their argument is weak and of no force, which ſay, that old age is not occupied in noble affaires and matters of great importaunce. And they do muche like, as if any man ſhould ſay that the Pylote and conductour of a ſhippe doth nothing, neither helpeth any thing in ſayling, when as ſome clymbe vp and ſit in the toppe of the Maſtes, ſome walk vpon the hatches, ſome clenſe the pumpe, but he holdinge the helme and ſtirring the rother, ſirteth quietlye in the ſterne or Puppe, and although he do not the ſame things, which yonge men doe, yet is his ſeruice farre better and greater then theirs. For matters of great waight, are not done wyth bodily ſtrength, nimblenes, celeritie and deliuerneſſe, but wythe counſaile, wiſedome, authoritie and pollicie, wherof old age accuſtomablye is not onelye not depryued,
but rather therewith the better increaſed, ſtored and furniſhed: vnleſſe peraduenture you thyncke, that I who haue bene bothe a Souldioure, a Tribune, a Marſhall of the fyelde, a Lieutenaunte of an armye, an Ambaſſ adoure and a Conſull, and throughlye tryed in diuerſe bruntes and hazardes of warres, do nowe abandon all my former valyaunce, and geeue my ſelfe to Idlenes, and to lyue vnprofytablye to the common wealthe, becauſe I haue ſurceaſſed frome warres and feactes of armes. But I do preſcribe ordres vnto the Senate, and ſhew to them what thinges in mine opinion are moſt expedient to be done, and géeue certaine informacion to them beforehand, how they maye make warre vpon the ſpightful Carthaginians, whoſe cancard harts haue a great while wiſhed & contriued our confuſion, whoſe malicious ſtomaks I ſhal neuer ceaſe to feare, vntil I know perfectlye, that their proude Citye is diſtroyed, ruynated and
vtterly ſubuerted. God graunte Scipio, that thou mayſte wynne the prayſe of that gloryous enterpryſe, and that it maye bée thy lotte, victoriouſlye to tryumphe ouer their vnſufferable inſolencye, repreſſynge theyr treacherous hawtyneſſe by fine force of armes and dente of Swearde, and that thou mayſt make a final ende of that, whych thy Graund-father made trybutarye: ſince whoſe deathe there are paſſed .xxxiii. yeares, but hys memoryall ſhall neuer bée forgotten, nor raſed oute of the myndes of all poſteritye. Hée dyed the yeare before I was Cenſour, nyne yeares after my Conſulſhyppe, whenne hée hadde béene elected and created Couſull the ſeconde tyme, I thanne hauynge the ſame office of Conſul. Thinke you that if hée hadde lyued tyll hée hadde béene a hundrethe yeare olde, hée woulde haue béene wearye of hys Olde age? hée woulde not vſe to make roades and incurſyons into hys ennemyes terrytoryes and dominions,
he would not giue himſelfe to leaping, dauncing and ſkipping, neyther to caſt dartes and toſſe pikes a farre of, nor with ſweards to fighte and claſpe with his aduerſirie hand to hand, but rather to envre himſelf with wiſedom, reaſon, conſultacion and iudgemente. Yf theſe poinctes had not bene in old men, our Predeceſſours woulde not haue called the ſupremedignitie of counſailours, by the name of Senate. Amonge the Lacedemonians they that bare the higheſte offices, as they be, ſo alſo are they called Auncients or Preſbiters. And if you bee diſpoſed, to heare and read forraine exā ples, you ſhall finde that noble and flouriſſhinge common wealthes haue bene broughte to ruyne and ſeruitude by the vnripe adminiſtracion of vnſkilful yong men, and the ſame by old & ſage fathers to haue bene maintayned, corroborated and recouered. Tell me this, howe loſte you your mighty and populous common wealth in ſo ſhorte ſpace? for to one that
moued this queſtion and demaunde (as it is to bée ſéene in the Booke of the Poete Naeuius which he entituled Ludus) many anſweres were made and namely thys: There ſtepped forthe, nevve and ſtraunge Oratours, fooliſhe and light headed young-men, vvho bearing chiefe rule and authoritie, vvith their vnaduiſed counſailes and peuiſhe raſhnes haue brought our commune vvealthe to a miſerable ſtate and deſolation. Raſhnes and temeritie is incidente to youthe, but prudence and pollicye to old age. But the memorie (you will perhappes ſay) in old men faileth and waxeth daylye worſe and worſe. I beleue it well, if a man do not vſe and exerciſe it, or if a man be of a dull and blockiſhe nature. Themiſtocles knew euery perſon in the Citie, and coulde cal euerye man by his proper name. Do you thinke, that in his old age, he vſed to name one man in ſtéede of another, and to ſalute Ariſtides in ſtede of Liſimachus. And I do not onely know them that ar yet aliue but their
fathers & Graundfathers alſo which are dead. Neither do I feare, whē I read the Epitaphes and inſcripcions of Tombes & graues, leaſt I ſhould therby, (as the cō mō credulity of people is) loſe my memory and remembraunce: for in reading of them I am brought into remembraunce of thoſe that are deceaſſed. Neyther did I euer heare of any old man ye had ſo weak a memory to forget in what place he laid his purſe & hidde his Treaſure. I warrāt you, they remember al ſuche thinges as they eſteme & ſet ſtore by, they wil not neglect nor forget their Obligacions, & billes of debt, nor their dayes of apperaunce before anye Iuſticiarie, vnto whom they be indebted, & who to them. They forget not what their counſailours in lawe do geue thē in charge, what their ordinaries & Prelates eniogne to them, what ye Augurs do prognoſticate, & what the Philoſophers do decide. Oh how many things do old mē remēbre? Old men haue their ſences & wittes freſh & vigorous ſo that they envre themſelues with exerciſe and induſtrie.
Which thing is euidētly and dayly to be ſene not only in men of great calling & honorable parentage, but alſo in priuate perſons & haſkerds of low degrée, liuinge quietly Sophocles compyled & made Tragedies, til he came to extreme old age, who being earneſtlye addicted to his ſtudies, was thoughte not to care or to take anye thought for his houſehold and domeſtical prouiſion, & therfore was he opēly accuſed of his owne ſonnes, & brought before the iudges, that they might defeate him from the vſe and poſſeſſion of his goods and riches and that (as the cuſtome and maner is alſo among vs, when any do negligently loke to their buſineſſe, ſuffringe their patrimonye & liuelyhode to fal in ruine & decaye) the iudges mighte depoſe & ſequeſtre him from the clayme & vſe of his goods, as an old doting cockeſcom. But he vnderſtā dinge their ſubtile & vnnatural dealinge, brought wt him to the iudgemēt hal, vnder his gowne a certaine Tragedie which he then had in hād & had lately writen, entituled Oedipus Coloneus, & red the ſame before the iudges demaūdinge of them whether they thoughte that Poeme to argue
any dotage in the writer? which when he had recited, he was by the ſentence of the Iudges acquited and diſcharged. Did old age cauſe this man, or Hiſiodus or Simonides, or Steſichorus, or Iſocrates or Gorgias (of whom I ſpake before) or Homere, or the prince of Philoſophers Pythagoras, Democritus, Plato, Socrates, or of later dayes Zeno, Cleanthes, or Diogenes the Stoicke, whom you perſonallye ſaw at Rome, to fainte and quaile in their ſcudies, or to be dryuen to ſuch a narowe iſſue that they had not a word to ſay? was not the earneſt and infatigable agitacion of all theſe mens ſtudies, equall to their life and conuerſacion? Go to, let vs omitte and ſpeake no more of theſe deuine and abſtruſe ſtudies. I can name diuerſe vplandiſhe huſbandmen of the Sabines, my neyghbours, and friendes, in whoſe abſēece their worke goeth ſo ſlowly forward, that nothinge almoſt is diſpatched about their huſbandrie, neyther in their tillage and ſowing of their corne
and fruictes, neyther in the gathering & bringing theim into their Barnes: albe it in them this is not ſo much to be meruailed at. For ther is no man ſo old, but he thinketh that he may liue one yere longer: and they toile about ſuche thynges, wherof they do wel know, that they ſhal not liue to enioy the profites. They plant and graffe trées which ſhal yelde fruicte, not to theym, but to their ſucceſſion and poſteritie, as our Statius in his booke called Synaephebis declareth. And if any huſbandmā (be he neuer ſo old) be demaunded and aſked, to whoſe behoufe he graffeth and ſoweth, he wil not ſticke to ſay: I ſowe for the immortal Goddes, whoſe pleaſure was, that I ſhould not receyue profittes fruictes and emolumentes at the handes of my Predeceſſours but reſpectiuelie and condicionally to leaue, ſurrendre & redeliuer the ſame or as much to my ſucceſſours. The ſaying of Caecilius which went afore, touching old men that laboured and prouided for their ſequele
and ſucceſſion, is farre better, then this followinge which he alſo wryteth: Certes, although old age vvhen it cometh, had none other inconuenience nor greuaūce ioyned with it yet this one is grefe ynough, becauſe by liuing long, a man ſeeth many things? vvhich he vvould not ſe. But I ſay & replye to it, that peraduenture he ſéeth many things which he is right glad and willing to ſe. And it oftētimes happeneth ye it is yong mens lot, to ſée ſuch things, as they are loth to ſée. But this next ſaying of the ſame Caecilius is as il, or rather worſe thē the abſurde ſentence ye wents before. I iudge & repute (ſayth he) this in old age to be moſte miſerable, becauſe a man perceiueth himſelf in that age, to be odious to them of yōger yeres. But I ſay ye age is rather pleaſaunte then odious. For euen as old aged men, being wiſe & vertuous, take great pleaſure & delighte in the compaignie of toward & godly nurtured yongmen, wherby their old age vnto them ſéemeth the more facile & tolerable, becauſe they ſe themſelues reuerenced
of youth: So likewiſe yongmen haue great comfort & contentacion in the holeſome leſſons and pithie preceptes which they heare of old men, wherby their mindes are enflamed & ſtirred to folow vertue & embrace honeſtie. And I do not ſée the contrarie, but you for your parts take as much pleaſure & are as glad of my cō paignie, as I am of yours. Now you plainly ſée, that old age is not only frée from al ſlouthful drowſines, & faint fée blenes, but is rather occupied and buſied in lawdable exerciſes, doing euer ſom thing, deuiſing & excogitating ſuch matters, as euery one in the freſh yeres of his former luſty age, was moſte envred withal. Yea they increaſe & augmente their knowledge, and leerne ſtil more & more, as we haue ſene by ye noble Lawmaker Solon, who great lye reioyced & in certain verſes gloried, ſaying, yt he waxed euery day an old man, by encreaſing his knowledge & learning daylie ſomwhat more, then he knew before as I my ſelfe alſo did, for I learned the Gréeke tongue whenne I was an
old man. Which with ſuch earneſt ſedulitie and inexpleble gréedines I learned or rather ſnatched vnto me, (albeit in my youth I vtterly cōtemned it) as thoughe it had béene a man muche deſyringe to quenche his longe and drie thriſte. And this I did to the entent I might aſpire & attaigne to the vnderſtandyng and ſkyll of thoſe things, whych you now ſée me to vſe for examples. And when I heard ſay, that Socrates in his old dayes did the ſame in Muſicall Inſtrumentes, I was alſo deſirous to haue done the like (for in old time, men commonly learned to play on Inſtruments) but in humanity and learnynge I trauayled diligently and toke paynes therin ful ſtudiouſly.

And now I do no more deſire to haue the ſtrength of a youngmā, (for this was the ſecond diſpraiſe and faulte that was laied againſt old age) then I did when I was younge, deſire to haue had the force and ſtrength of a Bul or an Olyphant. For what ſoeuer is engraffed naturally
in man, that is it fitte and decent to vſe, and in al thinges that he taketh in hand to labour & to do his diligente endeuour, accordinge to his ſtrengthe. For what words can there bée more contemptible, ſhameful, and abiect, then thoſe of Milo Crotoniata,
Milo diſprayſed for bewayling his lacke of ſtrēgth in his old age. who being old & ſeinge ſundrye Champions and wreſtlers exerciſing them ſelues and tryinge their force in the running place or field of exerciſe, is reported that he beheld his owne armes, and ſaid wéeping. Alas, theſe armes of mine that once were ſtrong and muſculous, are now dead? O thou vaine and light witted man, what a beaſt art thou to ſpeake ſuch fooliſh words? thy Armes are not ſo much deade, as thou arte thy ſelf. For thou ſéekeſt no fame, renowme and glory by thy ſelfe, but by thy bodely ſtrengthe and the highe bigneſſe of thy Armes and ſydes. Such fonde and vnadviſed wordes neuer proceded out of the mouth of Sextus Aemilius, nor T. Coruncanus that was many yeares before, nor
of P. Craſſus, ſince their dayes who were men of greate authority and wiſedome, who alſo appoincted & preſcribed lawes and ordres for the Romaynes: whoſe prudence perſeuered and honourably cō tinued til the very laſt houre of death. But I am afrayde,An obiection. leaſte an Oratoure through impotencie and debylitie of old age, muſt be forced to quaile and ſtay frō the practiſe of his profeſſion, becauſe his office and function conſiſteth not only in wytte and eloquence, but alſo in a loude durableneſſe, and ſtrainable voice, with other circumſtaunces belonging to vtteraunce. This ſhril and audible tenour of ſpeach & pronunciacion, forſaketh not an old man, no not in the extremetie of his age, but as a moſte beautifull grace (I know not how) doth accompaignie him to the end, Which I haue neyther loſt, neither do I thinke my ſelfe to be deſtitute of, and yet you both doſe my gray heares and my auncientie of yeres. Notwithſtā ding, a curteous and mylde ſpeach, and a
gentle, quiet or temperate vtteraūce purchaſeth the beneuolēt hearts of the multitude and much commendeth the partie in whome they are incorporate, yea a ſmoth and learned Oratiō ſpoken by an eloquent old mā, greatly deliteth the audience and maketh them attentiue. And although a man can not do theſe things himſelfe, yet maye he inſtruct Scipio and Laelius, and other towarde younge men. For what thinge is ſo pleaſaunt, as old age, guarded and enuironed with honeſt and ſtudious yongmen, being preſt, ready, and deſirous to ſhew and do their loyall obedience & dutiful reuerence? Shall we debarre old age from hauing authorite and power to teach, enfourme, chaſtiſe & admoniſh youth to do their duties, and to traine or frame them in vertuous dreade and godlye knowledge? Thanne which office, what can be more excellent or honourablye? Verelye, me thoughte that Caius and P. Scipio, and thy two Graunde fathers, L. Aemelius and P.
Africanus were happy and fortunate, by reaſon of the daylye compaignie of yong Gentlemen. And they whych are mayſters and profeſſours of the liberal artes and ſciences are to be taken and accompted no other wiſe, but bleſſed and fortunate: yea althoughe their ſtrength and firme luſtines of their bodies be decaied and imbecilled: albeit, this ſame decaye and fayling of the natural ſcrength doth oftener happen, through the default of adoleſcencie then of old age. For a libidinous and incontinent life, laſcyuiouſlye and inordinatly lead in youth, euer bringeth and deliuereth to olde age, a féeble, weake and impotent bodie. But kinge Cyrus, Goodlye examples of noble perſonages. of whome Xenophon writeth, amonge other his talke which he had, lying on his deathe bed, being a very olde man, ſayeth, that he neuer felte nor perceyued his old age anye whitte weaker or féebler then his adoleſcency and youth was. When I was a boy, I remembre L. Metellus, who after he had bene twyſe
Conſul, and foure yeres after his ſecond Conſulate, was elected & created Archprelate or high Prieſt, (which Prelacie & Prieſthoode he enioyed xxii. yeares) had in his olde age ſuche corporall ſtrength, that he neuer ſéemed to deſire or care for his adoleſcencie. I néede not héere to ſpeake any thing of my ſelf, although (if I ſhould) it were but the propertie of vs old men, and is by the priuiledge and reſpect of our age to vs permitted. Do you not ſée how oftentimes Neſtor doth celebrate and extoll his owne vertues, blaſing and recordinge his owne approued valiaunce, ioyned wythe prudence and pollicy, and bluſſhed not, with his owne mouth to make therof a moſt honorable mencion, as in Homere it is moſt manyfeſtly to be ſéene? He lyued thrée mens ages, and neded not to feare, Neſtor liued ccc. yeres. leaſt in diſplaying and ſoundinge oute of his owne prayſes, he ſhould be thought either arrogant or vainelie talkatiue For as Ho: mere wryteth and teſtifieth of him, there
iſſued and proceded oute of his mouthe moſte cloquente ſpeache, and ſugred woordes, ſwéeter then Honye, to the vtteraunce and declaracion of whyche his Pithye and pleaſaunte counſayles, hée néeded not anye robuſteous force of bedelye ſtrengthe:Wiſedō farre excellethe ſtrength. and yet Agamemnon Prince of Graecia and chyefe generall of all thoſe warlyke exploytes, neuer wiſſhed to haue tenne perſonnes, lyke to Aiax, but hée manye tymes wyſſhed that hée hadde had tenne ſuche as Neſtor was: Sayinge furthermore, that if hée hadde ſo manye Neſtors, hée woulde not doubte but that Troye ſhould within a ſhorte ſpace hee vtterlye ruynated and deſtroyed. But nowe to retourne and ſaye ſomewhat of my ſelfe. I am nowe goynge on my lxxxiii. yeare, and woulde to God, that I myghte make my vaunte, and glorye in that, for whyche Cyrus dydde in manner tryumphe and
thynke hym ſelfe happye: but yet thys canne I ſaye, that althoughe I haue not ſuche ſtrengthe as I hadde whenne I was a Souldyoure at the fyrſte warres betweene the Romaynes and the Carthaginians, or as I hadde, whenne I was in the ſame warres, in the offyce of Queſtor or generall receyuer, or as I hadde, whenne I was Conſull in Spayne, or as I hadde foure yeares after, whenne I was deputed Marſhall, of the fyelde, and foughte a battayle, wherein I dyſcomfayted the populons armye of proude Antiochus, and others of oure ſtyffenéecked Ennemyes that hadde encamped theymſelues in Baſtyles and Garryſons vppon the toppe of the greate Mountaynes and Strayctes called Thermopylae: Marcus Attilius, and C. Labeo beynge at that tyme
Conſuls: yet al theſe hazards and daungerous conflictes notwithſtanding, olde age hath not throughly afflicted neither altogether debilitated and exhauſted me. For neither the Senate, neither the Forum and Iudgemente Hall, neither my friendes and clientes, neyther my Gueſtes and ſtraungers (whom by the law of Hoſpitality I am bound and ought to defend) do find them ſelues deſtitute of my help, neither do eſpie any default or lack of ſtrength to be in me. And I neuer condiſcended nor agreed to this old approued prouerbe, of moſt men praiſed and commended, which willeth, that who ſo euer deſyreth to be an old man longe,This prouerbe ſemeth to be deuiſed by ſom freſh water Souldyour a gret deale fitter for a Carpet thenne a Campe. ſhoulde begin to be an old man betime & quickely: as who would ſay, that he ſhould now in his flouriſhinge and freſhe age deſiſt from trauaile and labour wherin youth delighteth, and altogether to prouide for eaſe and conſeruacion of his health. But I had leifer not to be an old man longe, then to be an old mā before I wer old in
deede. And therfore ther was neuer man yet to this day, that can ſay, that he euer came to ſpeake with me, but he found me occupied and doing ſomewhat. But I do confeſſe, that I haue not ſo much bodily ſtrength as either of you twaine hath: Again, neither of you, hath the ſtrength of T. Pontius the Centuriō. What then? is he therefore nobler and better then you are? Let ther be a moderaciō in ſtrength and let euery man attempt and aſſaie ſo much as he is wel able to compaſſe, and he that doth this, ſhal féele no great wāt of ſtrength, nor be agreued for the lacke thereof. In the famous games of Olympia, it is ſayd that the ſtrong Champion Milo cam in, carying on his ſhoulders a huge and bigge bodied Bull aliue, and bare him a furlong of: now, if thou were put to thy choiſe, whether haddeſte thou leifer haue the bodelye ſtrength of thys Milo, or els the quickenes of witte and the inward vertues of mynd, whiche the noble Philoſopher Pythagoras had? In
fine, vſe and take well in woorthe thys gyfte of bodily ſtrength, whyle thou haſt it, and when it is gone, do not deſyre nor ſéeke to haue it again, vnleſſe peraduenture you wyl ſay, that yonge men ought to wyſhe theim ſelues in theyr infancye and ſwathynge bandes againe, or when they be ſomwhat further ſtryken in yeares and in the maturitie or beſte tyme of their age, to wiſhe them ſelues agayne in theyr adoleſcēcy. The race and courſe of age is certayne, and there is but one way of nature and the ſame ſimple, and to euery part of a mans life and age, are géeuen hys conuenyente tymes and propre tempeſtiuytyes. For euen as weakenes and infirmytie is incident to yonge Chyldren, a luſtynes and brauerie to younge men, and a grauitye when they come to rype yeares: ſoe lykewyſe the maturitye or rypenes of olde age, hathe a certaine ſpeciall gifte, géeuen and attrybuted to it by nature, whych oughte not to bée neglected, but to bée taken in
hys due tyme and ſeaſon when it commeth. I thincke Scipio, that you heare by report, what your Hoſte, the moſte faithful confederate to the Romayn people, Maſiniſſa kynge of Mauritania doth now a dayes, beynge lxxxx. yeares olde.A worthye paterne of a valtaunt & fatherly prince. For whenne hee taketh anye voyage or iourneye, goinge at the firſt on foote, hée wyll not for that iourney ride nor come on horſebacke: and contrarywiſe, when hée rydeth foorthe on horſebacke, hée neuer vſéeth to alyghte of frome his horſe: no tempeſtuous weather, no ſtormes, nor colde canne make him to couer hys heade, but euer goethe bareheade hys bodye is ſoe drye, that hee is neuer moleſted with anye ſuch corrupt humoures as old men commonlye are infected and encombred withall, and therefore doothe hee in his owne perſonne execute al the offyces and functions that to a royall and noble Kynge do appertayne. Therefore exercyſe, moderate dyete and continēcy
are able to conſerue ſomwhat of a mans luſtines and former ſtrength, yea and that in olde age. Ther is (ſome ſay) no ſtrength in olde age: I anſwere that ſtrength is not required of old age, Therefore by the lawdable lawes and. holeſome ordinaunces, which our predeceſſours haue for ciuill order and publique vtilitie enacted, our age is diſpenced withall, exempted and diſcharged from al ſuche affaires as can not be withoute bodily ſtrength ſuſtayned and accompliſſhed. Wherby we are not compelled to do ye, which we are vnable to perfourme, yea wee are borne withall and not required to doe ſo much as we can do. But you wil againe obiect and ſay: Many old men are ſoe weake and feble, that they are not able to execute and diſcharge anye office or function that belongeth to mans life, and ſerueth for maintenance of vertue in humaine ſocietie. But truly the cauſe therof is not proprely to be imputed to the old age, but commonelye to
lacke of health. What a weake and impotent man was the ſonne of P. Africanus, euen hee, that made thee his ſonne by adoption? was not he ſo often aſſaulted and attained with diſcraſies and ſick neſſe, that hee was in a maner neuer healthful? which if it had otherwiſe happened, vndoubtedly he would haue prooued the ſeconde Myrroure and the moſte precious Iewel or ornament of our Cytie, nexte vnto his noble father. For to counteruaile the haute courage and incomarable proweſſe of his ſaide father, he was furniſſhed with greater learning and more abundant giftes of the mynd. What meruaile is it therfore in old mē, if now and then, they be ſicke and diſeaſed, ſith youngmen alſo are ſubiect to the ſame, and can not warrant them ſelues of health, no more then oldmē can? We muſt (deare frends Laelius and Scipio) reſiſt old age, and the inconueniences and faultes therof, muſt by diligence be recompenced and amended. And euen as
we muſte arme oure ſelues to fighte againſte infirmities and ſickneſſe, ſo alſo muſte wee ſtriue againſte old age. Wee muſt haue a good eye and a diligent reſpect to our health, and we muſt vſe moderate exerciſes of the bodye. We muſt not be to ingluvious,Prcceptes to be Welwaighed and obſerued on al hā des. in taking our foode and repaſte, wee muſte not pamper and gourmandiſe our ſelues withe exceſſe of meate and drinke, but ſo much and ſuch competencie thereof muſte be taken, as ſufficeth to refreſhe the vitall powers and naturall ſtrengthe, and not to empaire, hebetate, and vtterly to extinguiſh them. And we muſt not haue regarde to helpe the bodie onelye, but muche more to maintaine and conſerue the Memorie and reaſonable parte of man, whyche is the mind. For theſe are vtterlie defaced, extint and ſuffocated throughe to muche gluttinge fare, and rauenous ingurgitacion. And euen as a Lampe, if to muche oyle bee infuſed into it, burnethe not brightly, but yeldeth a very dymme and
darkiſhe lighte, againe, if it lacke oyle, it lacketh alſo lighte: ſoe likewiſe the mind is a like dulled & blunted, when the body is either ouercharged wyth ſuperaboundance and ſurfette, or els reſtraigned from the ſuffciencie that nature requireth. In olde age, naturall ſtrengthe eyther by defatigatyon, or els by ouermuch and vehement exerciſe drowpeth, and waxeth lumpiſhe and vnweldy: but the promptitude or readines of the wit and minde, is by beinge exerciſed, augmented, whetted and ſharpened. For thoſe old men whom the comical Poete Caecilius calleth fooliſhe, he meaneth to be ſuch as are credulous and light of beléefe, forgetful, remiſſe, diſſolute and neglygent about theyr buſineſſe, which are not the propre vyces and peculier faultes of Olde age it ſelfe, but of ſuche an Olde age, as is ſlouthefull, ſluggiſhe, drowſie, and géeuen more to ſleape and bellye théere, then to any good and lawdable exerciſe.
And as petulancie, malepertnes, and libidinous volupte bee vices ſoner to bee founde in younge men then in old men, (& yet al yong men are not ſurpriſed nor ſnared with thoſe beaſtly baites, but only ſuche, as are of naughtie diſpoſition & vnthriftie natures) ſo this foliſhnes that entangleth and captiuateth the ſenſes of old men (which is commonly called Dotage) is not in al old mē, but in thoſe only which are light witted, & kepe not them ſelues wythin the limittes of reaſon.

Appius being beſide his extreme olde age alſo blind, ruled and kept in awe his foure tall ſonnes, fiue daughters, his familye and houſehold (which was great) and entended the Patronage of his ſuppliaunt clientes, For he had his minde bent like a Bow, and neuer ſhronke for his yeres, neither ſuffred he Old age to haue the victory ouer him. He reſerued & kept his authoritye ouer all theym, that were vnder hys charge, and his family was ready at his becke and commaundement:
his ſeruaunts feared him, his children houored and reuerenced him, and al mē entierly loued him. In his houſehold the cuſtomes of his noble pedagrew and Aunceſtours, and the diſciplyne of hys Countrie toke place effectuallye. For herein is Old age honeſt and honourable: in defendinge and mayntayninge it ſelfe, in retayninge and kéepinge his authorytie, in ſauing it ſelfe frée from bondage and ſeruitude, and in exerciſinge rule and authorytie ouer them yt are vnder his charge, euē vntil the laſt houre of death. And as we do commend a younge man in whom appeareth any grauitie & rypenes of wytte, which to elder age ſemeth more incidente: ſo likewiſe do wee prayſe that old man, which hath ſome of the qualyties and propreties of a younge man of honeſte and ſobre demeanoure, which thinge who ſo euer marketh and foloweth, maye be old in bodye, but hée ſhal neuer be old in minde. I haue nowe in hande the ſeuenth booke of the Originalles,
and firſte foundacions of all the rityes in Italie, I do collecte and gather into one volume, all the notable monumentes of antiquity, and now preſently I am aboute the finiſſhinge of an other Booke, wherein ſhalbe contayned the Oracions of all ſuche famous cauſes, as I haue in my time defended. I am a ſerious ſtudiente and practyſer of ye Augurs lawe, the Canon, and the ciuyll Lawe. I géeue my ſelfe muche to the Gréeke tongue, and to exercyſe my memorye wythall,A notable exerciſe for ye memory. I doe as Pythagoras Scholers were wonte to doe: for what ſoe euer I haue harde, ſpoken or done the daye before, I call to remembraunce and debate the ſame with myſelfe in the euenynge. Theſe are the exerciſes of the wytte, theſe are the feates wherein the mynde is occupied, and theſe are the agitacions wherby it is ſtirred to vertuous operacions. I géeuing my ſelfe to theſe trades, and therein labouringe neceſſauntlye, doe not greatlye lacke, neyther thinke
my ſelfe deſtitute of bodelye ſtrengthe. When my friendes ſtand in néede of my ayde and helpe, I am preeſte and readye to ſtande them in ſtéede, I vſe many tymes to come into the Senate, and vnaſked I alledge and bringe many reaſons whyche wyth longe ſtudy I haue before premeditated and the ſame doe I mayntayne, vpholde, defende and ſupporte, not by ſtrengthe of bodye but of mynd. Yea although I were not able in proper perſonne to execute and put things in practyſe, yet ſhoulde I lyinge in my bedde, take greate pleaſure and delyte, by thynkyng and conſidering how to deuiſe and compaſſe thinges which I could not doe. But the life whyche heretofore I haue ledde, hathe bene and is ſuche, that I am able and canne do theym. For vnto him that ſpendeth hys tyme in ſuche laboures and ſtudies, old age is not perceiued when and howe it ſtealeth vppon him. Thus age waxeth old, and by lytle and lytle declineth as it weare inſenſiblye,
and it is not ſodainly amputated, or cut of, but by longe continnaunce and diuturnytie, is lyke a lampe, quenched and extinguiſſhed.

Now foloweth the third diſprayſe and fault which is layed in olde age, becauſe (ſaye they) it is wythoute pleaſure, and muſte forgoe voluptuous appetites. O noble and excellent gift, wherwith Old age is ſoe bleſſed, if it take frome vs that thing, which is in youth moſte vicious & deteſtable. But you (noble and vertuous gentlemen Scipio & Laelius) heare what Architas ye famous Philoſopher of Taren to, was wont to ſay, whoſe Oration touching the ſame matter was lent and deliuered to me, when I was a yong man and ſerued vnder Q. Maximus at the ſiege of Tarento. He ſayd, that no plague was géeuen by nature ſo great and pernicious vnto men, as the beſtiall pleaſures, and voluptuouſnes of the bodye. Which pleaſures, the diſſolute and libidinous luſtes of men do ſo much affecte
and deſire, that with all licentious prophanacion and outrage, their minds bée incyted and ſtirred to purſue the ſame, thinking al thinges lawful for their vnbrideled appetites, ſo that they maye enioy their beaſtly deſires and ſtill wallow in the fylthie puddle of their helliſh ſenſualitie. Hence (ſaide he) as from a fountaine do ſpring out al kinds of miſchief, as Treaſon, betraying of countraies, the ruyne and ſubuerſiō of comon wealthes, ſecret conuenticles and priuye conferences with the enemyes:Pleaſure is the bayte of al miſchiefe. finally (he ſayde) there was none ſo greate a villanie, nor anye ſo flagitious and horrible an enormitye, whyche the inordinate deſyre of pleaſure would not egge and pricked forwarde mens frowarde willes to enterpriſe: furthermore that whoredome, adultrie and all ſuche like heynous factes of carnall concupiſcencie were by noone other lures or enticements proucked but by pleaſure. And whereas eyther nature or god hath géeuen vnto man nothing of
ſo noble excellencye as the mynd or reaſonable ſoule, there is nothing ſo greate an ennemye vnto this ineſtimable and deuyne gift, as pleaſure, For wher pleaſure beareth ſwaye and ruleth the roſte, there is no manſion nor dwellyng place lefte for Temperaunce and Sobrietye, and to bée ſhort, vertue can not remaine where pleaſure raigneth. Which thing, that it myght the better be vnderſtanded and more euidentlye bee perceyued, hée badde, that a man ſhould ymagine and in bys mynde preſuppoſe ſome manne to bee captiuated, ouerwhelmed and altogether plunged in as muche of this beaſtly Pleaſure as he coulde conceiue: whyche beinge doone, he thought there would bée no man whoſe ſenſes were ſo muche bounde vppe in the vaile of ignoraunce, but bee woulde eaſelye iudge, that ſuche a man, ſo long as hys mynde was thus paſſionated, wyth ſuche brutiſhe and filthye affections, coulde not contryue or compaſſe any honeſt action,
nor rule him ſelfe by reaſon and honeſtie. And therfore, ther is nothing ſo peſtilent, ſo execrable and hurtful as pleaſure. For if it ſhoulde enter into mans hart and there longe bare dominacion, it would quighte marre, deface and extinguiſhe al the light of the mind, which is reaſon and vnderſtandynge. Nearchus in whoſe houſe I lodged in Tarento, whoe alſo ſheewed him ſelfe verie friendlye to the Romaine people, ſayd, that he hadde heard his aunceſtours and elders report, that Architas ſpake al theſe words, whē the Romayne Conſuls P. Poſthumius & T. Veturius were diſcomfited and ouerthrowen by the Samnites, who had enuironed and entrapped them like fiſhes in a nette or Buckes in a Buckſtall in the perillous ſtraytes and difficile entries of Caudium. C. Pontius the valiaunt Samnite and his father being then the cōductours and captaines general of the Samnites armie. Plato alſo the noble A thenian Philoſopher, was preſent & heard him
ſpeake theſe wordes, whom I do in olde hiſtories fynd, that he came and arriued at Tarento, when L. Aemilius and Appius Claudius were Conſuls. But to what purpoſe do al theſe circumſtancies tend? Trulye that you may vnderſtande, if we cannot be perſwaded by reaſon and wiſdome, to abandonne our wantonnes and mortifye oure pleaſures, yet that we are muche bounden and beholdinge to olde age, by whoſe meanes we are ſo temperately diſpoſed, that we haue no luſte to do any thing, which is vnderēt or vncomly to be done. For pleaſure being a deadly and mortall enemye to reaſon, hindereth vertuous action and prudent conſultacion, and the eyes of the mind thereby are ſo iuggled and bewitched, that it can haue no felowſhip nor compaignie with vertue. Sore againſt my wil was it, whē I depoſed and dyſgraded L. Flaminius, (brother to the worthye and hardie gentleman T. Flaminius) of his ſenatourſhip. ſeuen yeares after hee had bene Conſul:
but yet I well conſidered and wyth my ſelfe waighed, that it was expedient and needefull that his lawleſſe and vicious déede ſhould not eſcape due puniſhment, becauſe impunitie manye times doth animate men of ſemblable diſpoſition an other time to bee the bolder to attempte further miſchiefe by geuing the bridle to their owne licentious will and ſenſuall affections. For when hée was apoincted Conſul in Lumbardie, he was at the citie of Placence, requeſted by a Curtiſaine or common harlott at a banquet,Gallica Ciſaiona to cauſe ſome one of his captiues whom hée had taken and kepte in priſon and adiudged to dye) to be preſently in her ſight beheaded, becauſe the bloudy Strumpet (as ſhe ſayd) had neuer ſéene any executed: vnto whoſe deſire and requeſte he relented, & forthwith commaunded one of theym to be put to death. And duringe the time yt his brother Titus was Cenſor, (whyche dignitye he enioyed next before me) hée eſcaped, and was neuer therefore puniſhed.
But when I and Flaccus wer made Cenſors, we could not brooke ſuch enormytie nor wynke at ſuche a ſelfe willed exaumple, becauſe he abuſed and blemiſſhed the honoure of our noble Empyre, with hys priuate lewdnes and ſhameful ſenſualitie. I haue oftentymes hearde our elders ſay, (whych they alſo as they reported, had heard of their fathers and old predeceſſours when they wer boyes) that C. Fabritius was wont much to mernaile, becauſe on a tyme when hee was ſent on an Ambaſſade to Pyrrhus kynge of ye Epyrotes, he heard one Cyneas (who was borne in Thaſſalia and was the kinges Scholemaſter) report and tel, how yt ther was a certain man of Athens, Epicures which profeſſed himſelf to be a wiſe man, & ſay, yt al our actions, thoughts & dedes what ſo euer they were, oughte to be referred only to pleaſure, as to the principal end, repoſing therin our chiefeſt felicitie. M. Curius and T. Coruncanus, hearyng this abhominable aſſertion and deuiliſh opinion,
whiche Fabricius tolde, oftentymes wiſſhed that the Samnites, and Pyrrhus himſelfe, were reſolued and perſwaded to beléeue and credite the wordes of that prophane helhounde: becauſe if they would enthral and addict them ſelues to diſporte daliaunce, vanitie and pleaſure, they might the ſoner be conquered, and their proude ſtomackes appaulled. This M. Curiꝰ liued with P. Decius, euē he that in his fourth Conſulſhippe, fiue yeeres before the Conſulate of Curius, voluntarily gaue himſelfe to deathe for the ſafegarde and preſeruacion of hys Countrie. Fabricius knew hym, & ſo did Coruncanus alſo, who aſwell by their owne lyfe, as by thys woorthye facte of Decius of whome I nowe ſpake, iudged and thought that there was ſomethinge naturallye good, fayre, excellente, and for it ſelfe onely expetible, which euery good and vertuous man ſhold and ought to loue, honour & embrace, abandoning and vilipending al ſenſual pleaſure and
looſe diſhoneſtie. But to what purpoſe do we ſpeake ſo much of pleaſure? Verily, to thintent that hereby it may be ſene and proued, how that it can not onelye, not be obiected to Old age for any vituperation and diſpraiſe, but rather for a ſiuguler prayſe and commendacion, becauſe old age dothe not eſtéeme nor care for theſe pleaſures. But ſome other wil ſaye: It lacketh ſumptuous fare, coſtlye diſhes, delicate viande, and drinkes of all ſortes: Hereto I aunſwere, that therfore, it lacketh alſo dronkennes, cruditie or indigeſtion, phantaſtical dreames and ridiculous apparitions. But if we muſt any whitte yeld to pleaſure (becauſe we cannot eaſily reſiſt the blandiments and allurementes therof, (for the deuine philoſopher Plato calleth pleaſure the baite of all miſchiefe,Pleaſure the bayte of al miſchiefe. becauſe men therewithe are caught and ſnared euen as fiſhes are wyth the hooke) I ſaye, that althoughe old age be not endaungered nor géeuen to ſuperfluous and immoderate banqueting
and at vnſeaſonable houres, yet in temperate and moderate feaſting it may be ſolaced and comfortablye recreated. I my ſelfe when I was a boy, haue oftentimes ſene C. Duillius the Soune of Marcus, (the ſame that firſte vanquiſhed the Carthaginians in terrible fighte on the Sea) retourne home being an olde man from the place where he hadde ſupped: hee woulde manye times haue a linke or a toorche caried before hym, and a mynſtrell alſo playinge on a ſhaulme, whiche no pryuate perſon before hym euer did: his warlicke exploites and tryumphant victoryes ſhold (as he thought) be to him for this licentious libertie and new begonne cuſtome, a ſufficient warrantiſe. But to what ende doe I recite ſo much of others? I wyl now ſpeake ſomwhat of my ſelfe: firſte I haue alwaies had ſome of my compaignions and frendes at my table, when I toke my ordinarie repaſte. For the order of fraternities and aſſemblies of honeſte and ſobre perſonages,
moderately to bāquet one with an other was inſtituted and made when I was Queſtor, and for the more regall furniture and pompous ſolemnizacion of this Ceremonie, the image or picture of Cybele who is called the mother of the Goddes, with al the rites and obſeruances therto belonging was broughte and cōuaighed to Rome out of Phrygia. I therfore moderatlye banqueted and within the bondes of ſobrietie I vſed to ſolace my ſelfe, & merylie to make good chéere with my Coequalls. But I was then, in the luſtie floures of myne age, and there was in me a certaine heate of Iuuenilitie, whiche (as age groweth and encreaſeth) is qualefied, and al things brought to a conueniente and tractable decencie. Neither did I take delectacion in theſe banquettes and epulacions for bodelye pleaſure and glutting gourmandyſe, but rather for the compaignye and talke of my frendes and welwillers. Therfore oure elders and predeceſſours did verye
wel, to terme a banquet or feaſt, wherat frends do meat together, by the name of Conuiuium: becauſe it hath a coniunction of liuing together one with an other, & therin they termed it much better then the Gréekes do, for the name which they géeue it, ſignifieth as much as a Compotacion,Sympoſium. as though frends méete together purpoſely to quaffe and drinke: And a cō cenaciō or a comeſſation, as though they aſſembled for the chéere or the meates ſake: wherin they ſeme to alow & comend that moſt,Synepnium whiche is the leſt parte of the goodnes that therein is to be taken. But I am delyted in feaſtes and banquettes beinge made in ſeaſonable and conueniente times, for the ſolace and pleaſure whyche I take in learned conference and colloquyes of wyſedome, and that not onely wyth my equalles and theym that are of the ſame age that I am, (wherof the numbre is now verye fewe and ſmall) but alſo wyche you twayne, and other younge gentlemen of freſher
yeres, And I hartely thanke old age for this boone & good turne, becauſe it hathe increaſed in me an earneſt deſire of talk, and debatinge of ſerious matters withe men of approued learning and grauytie, but the gréedie deſire of meat and drinke it hath taken awaye from me: Notwithſtanding, if any old man bee delighted in theſe blandiments of pleaſure (I meane good chéere & daintie fare, (leaſt I ſhould ſéeme to ſtand at open defiaunce and denounce warre to all pleaſure, whereof peraduenture ther is ſom natural cauſe meane and reaſon) I can not ſée, howe olde age either lacketh or is deſtitute of ſenſe and féeling, no not in theſe kindes of pleaſures, which ſerue for the palate & toth, which we before declared. The ſuperioritie, which the chife ruler of the feaſt hath aboue others, by an order whyche our aunceſtours inſtituted, doth greatly contente and pleaſe my mynde: and the merie pleaſaunte queſtions or Caſes, whiche he by an olde lawdable cuſtome
proponeth to the compagnie to be diſputed vpon, and reaſoned at the table, and the Cuppes of drinke not ebriouſly ſwilled but moderatlye taſted, beinge alſo ſo cleane rinſed and waſſhed, that the cleare droppes of pure water ſtand and cleaue to the ſides, as it wer the ſwete droppes of holeſome dewe, much like to the compotation and feaſte whereof Xenophon wryteth: and a place to coole our wearie membres in the heate of Sommer, and in the ſturdy and nipping cold of winter, eyther the warme Sunne, or els a good fyer, is vnto me a ſinguler contentation. Theſe orders and dietes am I wonte to obſerue, whē I ſeiourne in my Manours and houſes of Sabinum, and euery daye I ſe my table furniſhed with the apoincted numbre of my neyghbours neare adioyning, and with talking of diuers matters we prolonge and continewe oure ſupper ſometimes till it be farre in the nighte, euery man layinge in for himſelfe ſuche reaſons and argumentes as hee hath for
the corroboration and confirmation of his cauſe and aſſertion. Obiecti∣on But there is not in old men ſo great a deſire of Carnalitie nor ſuche ticklinge concupiſcence of venerie. I beléeue it well: and it is not onelye frée, from the aſſaultes and pricking luſt therof, but alſo from any deſire or delite at al therunto. For nothinge is gréeuous or heauilie taken of a man, if he neither care nor deſire the ſame. Sophocles being an aged man, was aſked of one, whether hee gaue himſelfe to anye venerous daliaunce and coiture? Vnto whom he aunſwered & ſaid: god forbidde that I in this age ſhould geue my ſelf to ſuch wanton luſtes, for I haue willingly renounced and fledde awaye frome that kinde of laſciuiouſnes, as from a thinge whiche I know to be like to a Lordlye & imperious maiſter, both beaſtly, ſauage, and furions. But to theym that are deſirous therof, it is a greate griefe to lacke and be wythout it: but to theym whyche haue ſatyſfyed theyr naturall luſtes,
whoſe age fitte for ſuch wantonneſſe is alreadye expired, it is more pleaſure to lack then to vſe it. Albeit he that forceth not for it, can not be ſaid to lacke it, therfore not to care for it (I ſay) is more pleaſure then to haue ful fruition and ſacietye of it. Now wheras adoleſcencye delighteth more in theſe pleaſures, the cauſe is becauſe it is more willinge and procliue to folow the things whyche are of ſmall moment and importaunce, as it is of it ſelfe raſhe and wauering: but afterwarde ſuche thinges as olde age is delighted and geuen to, the whiche althoughe it doe not fully enioye, yet doth it not altogether lacke. Euen as hee that ſitteth on the chyefeſte benche in a Theatre or Liſtes where playes and Enterludes are exhibited, is more delyted to ſée the excellent geſture of Ambiuius Turpio, and his incomparable dexteritye in the expreſſe imitation and geſture of anye perſonne, yet hee that ſtandeth a farreof, lookynge ouer other
mens ſhoulders hathe ſome delectation aſwell as the others: ſo like wiſe youth and adoleſcencie being by reaſon of their freſhe age, more prone to pleaſures than old age is, hauing and daylye ſéeing the allurements therof more neere to them, is perhappes more frolicke: but old age ſéeing them a loofe and a farre of, is ther in delited as much as is requiſite and expedient. But what a ſinguler commoditie is this, that ye mind like an old worne Souldioure is by the meanes of old age raunſomed and exempted from the vglie ſeruitude and thraledome of ſenſualitie, voluptuouſnes, ambition, ſtryfe, contention, quarelling, ennemitie, and finallie from al lothſome and fylthy affections, and in ſteede thereof to embrace mediocritie and moderacion, and to be contented and to liue (as the old ſaying is) with him ſelfe? But if it be furniſſhed withe ſtudie and learning, (which are as it wer the nutriture and ſuſtentaciō of old age) truly nothinge is more pleaſaunt then it
is, being diſmiſſed from all troubleſome entermedlinge with publique affaires & wholly addict to quiet contemptation.Old men ſtudious. We ſaw C, Gallus the famous Aſtronomer and greate friende to thy father O Scipio, ſo intentiuelye addicted to his dimenſions aſwel of heauen as of earthe, that he ſéemed to haue none other delite, neither to haue any reſpect at al, for any other worldly buſines. How many nightes did he beſtow vpon ſtudie of that facultie, and neuer ſlepte? How often hath the next morowe appered ere he had left his lucubrations, which he had begonne ouer night? How often did nighte come vpon him, when he had inceſſauntly laboured in his Calculations Aſtronomicall all daye before, withoute meate or drinke? What a ſinguler pleaſure was it to him, long beforehand to prognoſticate and forſhewe the Eclipſes boothe of the Sunne and Moone? what painful laboures ſuſtayned he in the ſtudie of other matters not of ſo greate momente
and importannce as theſe other, but yet verye ſubtile, quicke and wittie? Howe greatlye reioyced Naeuius in his comedye whych he entituled the Punique vvarre? Howe did Plautus in hys Comedye called Truculentus in manner leape & tryumphe for ioye? wythe what gladnes was hee ſurpryſed wythal, whenne bee hadde wrytten an other comodye named Pſeudolus? I ſaw Liuius, who hauynge ſet foorth an Enterlude ſeuen yeres before I was borne, when Cethegus and Tuditanus weare Conſuls, lyued and flouriſhed tyll I was a bigge ſtripling. What ſhoulde I ſpeake of the worthye and expert Lawyer P. Licinius Craſſus, and of his wouderful knowledge bothe in the Canon and in the Ciuile Lawe? or of the induſtrious contemplation and dyligence of this our P. Scipio, who was of late created high Prieſt? And all theſe whome I haue heere named, wee haue ſéene being old men to géeue theymſelues to ſtudye. But as for M. Cethegus,
whom Ennius doth very proprely cal the verye pythe and marowe of Suada the Goddeſſe of eloquence and pleaſaunte ſpeache, how ſtudiouſly dyd we ſee hym, bente to the arte of Rheiorike & Oratorie in his olde age? what pleaſures eyther of banquetyng, of playes, or of brothelles and Curtiſans are comporable to theſe vertuous and lawdable pleaſures? Theſe are the ſtudyes of doctrine and learnynge, whyche in men of wiſedome and good inclynation, doe growe and increaſe, euen as they theym ſelues doe in age accordyng to that golden ſayinge of Solon, who in a briefe pooſye or ſentence ſayd (as we before haue ſhewed) that hee waxed euerye daye olde,The ſayinge of wiſe Solon. by learnynge daylye ſome knowledge whereof he was before ignoraunt: then whych pleaſure of mynd, there can none bee greater, none more vertuous, none more commendable. I will now ſpeake of the goodlye pleaſures, whyche Huſbandmen haue, wherin I my ſelfe haue
