great delighte, whiche are not hindered by old age,I Inſbandrye. and in my opinion their lyfe is moſt like to a bleſſed and happie mans life. For their traphique and trade of marchandiſe is with the earthe, whyche neuer refuſeth to be vnder their rule and ſubiection, neuer is ſo diſobediente nor obſtinate, but obedient and ſeruiciable, and repayeth with great increaſe of vſurie (as who would ſaye for the vſe & lone of their ſéedes and toyle) that which it receyued, but at ſometime it doth not rendre ſo much as it doth at an other time, albeit for the moſt part, it requireth their trauailes with a greate ſurpluſage and acceſſe of gaine. But yet, I doe not onely take pleaſure, in the fruictes and grains which it yeldeth, but alſo in the ſtrength, nature and power of the earthe it ſelfe, which receyuing the ſéede in her lappe, and beinge by tillage and good huſbandrie plowed, mollified and well manured, doth for a time at the firſt kéepe and nouriſhe it, beinge couered within it by
harrowing, which is therfore called Occatio, then doth it make it to appeare and péepe oute of the ground, throughe the warmth which it receiueth by the vapourous humyditye, and amicable heate, and ſo cheariſſheth it, that in time it bringeth forth a gréene ſtalke lyke at the firſte to graſſe or herbes, the which being ſtrengthened by the ſmal ſhootes and ſtringes that growe out of the roote, doth by lytle and litle growe vp to a bigge ſtemme, & ſtanding vpright vpon a knottye ſtraw full of ioyntes, (when it nowe waxeth & draweth nere to ripenes) is included in pods or huſkes. Out of the which, as out of a ſheath or hoſe, there commeth forth corne or graine, whiche lay in the eare fenſed, fortifyed and armed againſte the pecking and eating of ſmall byrdes with a Rampier or wal of the awnes or beardes. What ſhoulde I recite and declare the plantinge and pruning of vynes, the increaſing and proffites of them? I can not ſufficiently tell you, what incredible
ioye and pleaſure I take therin, how my mynde is ſet therein, and this I ſaye, to thentent, that you may throughly vnder ſtande the quietneſſe and recreation of myne old age. I omitte to ſpeake of the vertues of al ſuch thinges as the earthe bringeth forth: how of one ſmal kernell of a figge, or one lytle corne or graine of a grape, and finally of other lytle ſéedes of all other fruictes graynes and yonge ſhootes it bringeth forth and procreateth ſuch greate boles and mightye bodyes, and in frucites or herbes ſuche hyghe ſtemmes. The ſmal twigges that bee cut of from the vynes to bee planted els wher, the yonge ympes and griftes, the ſuperfluous braunches that are pruned, the plantable vynes, the vaulted and arched herbours that are made for pleaſaunte walkes, whereon the vynes maye renue and ſpread abroade and refreſhe men wythe their coole vmbrage, the euttynge downe of olde vynes, that yonge ſlyppes may theron be ſet, woulde
not all theſe allure a manne to loue and haue theym in admiration? The vine is naturally ſtowping and fallyng downewarde, and if it be not with ſhoores and forkes vnderpropped, it groweth toward the grounde: but the ſame by the helpe and furtheraunce of hys tendrelles, whych are to it in ſteede and lieu of handes, raiſeth vp it ſelfe, catcheth, and lappeth it ſelfe faſt, to what ſoeuer it commeth neare, the which in contynuaunce of time wandring and rouing at randon vncomptrolled, and entangling it ſelfe with many other parts, at length the vigilant care and diligent hand of the huſbandman doth by pruning reſtraine, and with his vine hookes ſo cutteth & kepeth vnder, that it can not grow to luxuriouſly nor wieldlye, neither be ouer growen with ſuperfluous braunches, & ſpread out to farre on euerye ſide with buſſhie ruggedneſſe. And therfore in the beginning of the Springe tyme, ther commeth oute a younge bourgen or budde in thoſe
twigges that remayned after the pruning, which do as it were grow oute at the very ioyntes, where thoſe ſuperfluous braunches were lopped and cut of: out of which burgeins, the Cluſter doth procéede and appeare, which takinge increaſe and growinge in bigneſſe, what with the bumyditie & iuyce of the earth, and what with the warmth and heate of the ſunne, is for a while at the firſte ſower and vitter in taſte, but whenne it is rype and mature, it is bothe ſweete, and tothſome, and being couered and cladde wyth leaues, it receyueth thereby ſuche comforte and helpe, that it neyther lacketh expedient and needefull heate, and alſo defendeth it ſelfe from the parching and ardent beames of the Sunne. Now, what can be either for profit more pleaſaunt, or for the ſight and delyting of the eye more gorgious and beautiful, then theſe afore named pleaſures? Whoſe profitable vſe, and gainful poſſeſſiō, doth not only (as I ſaid before) meruailouſly
content and pleaſe me, but alſo the manuring, the digging, and the proper nature therof, is vnto mée pleaſure incredible. The order of the ſtayes or ſhores, wherby the vines are vnderpropped, the tyinge and plattinge of theym together wherby men haue a pleaſaunt and ſhadie galerie to walke in, the byndinge of theym downe, their increaſe and ſpreadinge abroad, the prunyng of the ſuperfluous braunches, and the new graffing of others in their places (which I ſpoke of) repleniſhe my heart with ioy vnſpeakeable: To what purpoſe ſhould I here rehearſe the watringe and irrigation of the plantes, the trenches and deluing of the grounde, the repaſtination or newe digging aboute the rootes, whereby the grounde is made much more fartile and ranke? whereto ſhoulde I ſpeake of the profitte that commeth by dunginge the ground? wherof I haue at large ſpoken in my booke entituled Of Huſbandrie: al be it the aunciente and learned Poete
Heſiodus ſpeaketh neuer a word therof, in his woorke of Tyllage and Ruſticall affaires. But Homere who (as farre as I can gather) was long before Heſiodus) in troduceth and bringeth in olde Laertes, (ſore longing and languiſſhinge for the abſence of his ſonne Vlyſses) after the maner of a huſbandmanne, tyllinge and dunginge his grounde. And the trade of Huſbandrye is not onely pleaſaunt and plentiful, enriched and ſtored with corne, graine, Meadowes, Vineyeardes, hopyeardes, groues and other places where Trées growe: but alſo with Orchardes, Gardeins, féedyng of Cattal, Swarmes of Bées, and variety of al kynd of ſwete flowers. And not only ye ordrely ſettyng and ſtanding of the Trées and plantes. delite and pleaſe the eyeof the beholder, but alſo the Inſitions and graffinge of younge Slyppes in an other trée: which poinctes and feactes are as wittye and ſubtyle, as anye are in Huſbandrye. Manye oblectamentes of Huſbandmen
could I declare, but I wel perceiue, that in theſe few commodities whych I haue already tolde, I haue bene to prolixe and tedious. But you ſhal of youre courteſye beare with my feruent zeale, and pardon my earneſte proſccution of my reaſons and argumentes therin. For, the greate good wil and loue, which I haue and ſtil do beare to Huſbandrye, hathe enforced mee to ſpeake and wade further in it, thenne at the firſte I purpoſed: and alſo Olde age is reported to bée by nature talkatiue and géeuen to loquacitie, (becauſe I wyll not ſée me to auouche and ſaye that it is cleare and frée from al maner of vyces and faultes. And therefore the valyaunt and inuincible duke Manius Curius, when he had atchieue manys notable exploytes and glorious vyctoryes agaynſte the rebellyous foes and Capytall Ennemyes of the Romayne people, and had ſhewed hymſelfe a Mirroure of proweſſe and knightelye fortitude in ſundrye hazardes, after hée had
tryumphed ouer the Samnites & Sabines, and hadde ſubdued the couragious and myghtye Pyrrhus, kynge of Epyrotes, & ſubiugated al his Territories,Huſbandrie vſed of noble and valiaunt mē. Seigniories and dominions by dent of ſweard and ſtroke of battaile, vnto the Romaine nation, liued in hys old age in this kynd of life: whoſe poore manſion as often as I do beholde (for it adioyneth nere vnto my ſermes) I can not but greatlye meruaile and bee aſtonned, eyther to ſée the continencie of this noble man, or els the condition & diſcipline that was in thoſe dayes. And when the Samnites after their diſcomfiture, came to this Curius, offring him great foyſon and ſummes of golde, they founde him in his owne houſe, ſittinge by the fyre, and ſéething Rape rootes in an earthen pot or pipkin, who cō ſtantly refuſed al their offers and rewardes, telling them in flatte woordes, that he thought it not ſo greate honoure and glorye to poſſeſſe gode,An ennemic to bribes & rewards as to beare rule & to be Lord ouer them, whych had gold.
How could this noble and valiaunt heart otherwiſe chooſe, but leade an olde age moſt pleaſaunte? But I wil take holde where I left, and ſpeake of huſbandmen as I did before, becauſe I take my ſelfe as one of their order and felowſhippe. Senatours, that is to ſaye, ſage and olde gray headed Counſailours, wer in thoſe dayes Huſbādmen, for as Lucius Quintiꝰ Cineinnatus was holdinge the ploughe & earneſtlye toylinge in his tillage in the fyelde, newes were brought to him that he was elected Dictator: vpō the hearing wherof he ſtraight waies left his plough and came to Rome, and was enſtalled in the ſame office of Dictator or hyghe mayſter of ye people, executing the ſame withe all ſingleneſſe and ſynceritie, by whoſe commaundement, his vicegerent or Lieutenaunte Caius Seruilius Hala, Captayne of the Horſemen, ſlewe Spurius Melius a miſerable and ambitious man, traiterouſlye aſpiting to be kyng. Oute of their fermes and countrie houſes,
Curius, and manye other old menne were chooſen into the honourable ſocietie and orders of Senaours: whervpon, the officers, or Purſeuauntes whiche ſommoned and called theym to the Senate were named Currours Poſtes, or ſpecyall Meſſengers. Was therfore the old age of theſe men miſerable, whiche refreſſhed and ſolaced theym ſelues in tillage and Huſbandry? Certes, in mine opynion, I iudge that there can bee no life more bleſſed and fortunate thenne thys is, and not onelye for the honeſte exerciſe and néedeful commoditie which thereby to al mankinde redoundeth (for if Tillage were neglected al the ſorte of vs woulde bewayle the lacke and féele the ſmarte thereof) but alſo becauſe of the delectation (as is before ſayde) and the plentyfulues or aboundaunce of all thinges, whiche eyther to the conſeruation of manne, his foode and nutriment, or els to the worſhippe and adoration of the goddes are requyſitie and conuenable.
And becauſe manye doe wiſhe and deſire this, let vs reconcile our ſelues, & make a firme peace & infringible atonemente with Pleaſure. For euery good and ſubſtantiall houſeholder hathe euer his Sellers for wyne and oyle, and other offices for prouiſion of houſehold repleniſſhed and well ſtored, yea his whole houſe is with al néedeful vtenſiles in al poincts furniſſhed, it is neither deſtitute of Hogge, Kidde, Lambe, poultrie ware, Mylke, Chéeſe nor hony. Now huſbandmen them ſelues, find their Gardeine ſo commodious vnto them, (becauſe it myniſtreth and bringeth foorthe plentye of good herbes, wherwith they make them Saleties and lyue well contented with their golden mediocritye, and becauſe it was euer readye at hande and needed no fyre to dreeſſe and ſéethe theym) that they called it an other Larder or fleſhe ſhambles:Hor • us • altera ſuccidia. alſo theſe ſame gardeine herbes being their daily foode and ſuſtentation are by hunting and hawking made
more pleaſant and tothſome, althoughe theſe be exerciſes, which do not neceſſarily belong to Huſbandrie, but are rather ſuperuacuous and vaine. What maye I now ſay of the gréene verdure and goodly hewe of the ſwéete Meadowes, or the ordrely ſetting of Trées, or of the fourme and beautye of vines, and places beſette with direct rowes of Oliue Trées? I wil in few words ſhew, what I think herein. Ther can nothing be either for vſe more commodious, or for profitte more gainfull, or for the gazing view of the gréedie eye more trymme and elegante, then a wel tilled and manured fielde, from the fruition of whych ſo great and bleſſed a thinge, Old age bringeth vnto man not onely no hindraunce nor impedimente, but rather inuiteth & allureth him vnto it. For wher may old age be ſo wel warmed either by breathing and ſitting againſte the hoate ſunne, or by a good fier: or contrarywyſe, as the time and ſeaſon of the yeare ferueth, bee ſo holeſomlye cooled
in ſhadye places, or be ſo aptlye bayned as in the countraye? Let vs therfore bid adieu to al ſuch youthly prankes and exerciſes, as luſtye and gréene headed Galantes agitated and pricked wythe the feruent heate of vnaduiſed adoleſcencye, do envre them ſelues withal, god ſpéede them wel with their vſual diſportes and daliaunce, let them take to theymſelues their armoure, weapons, and Artillerie, let vs permit and géeue them good leaue to daunte fierce Horſes, and with ſpeares in reſt to mount on couragious courſers, let theym handle the pike, toſſe the Iaueline and Clubbe dayly, and play at the Tenyſe, exerciſe theym ſelues with runnynge, Swymminge, and ſuche like déedes of actiuitie and nymbleneſſe: to vs olde men amonge all their other games and paſtimes, lette theym leaue the Tables, the Chaunce bone or dyce, and the Cheſſe, whiche without any daunger or ſore ſtrayning of the body maye be practiſed: and yet I wil not ſéeme to •… owe
theſe laſte named games, further then euery man himſelfe is diſpoſed, becauſe they be not neceſſarie, and old age maye without theym be bleſſed and fortunate. The bookes of Xenophon are very expedient and profitable for many purpoſes, the which I would wiſhe, that you ſhold read ouer and pervſe dyligentlye, as you do. How copiouſly doth he extol & praiſe huſbandry in his booke which he wrate of the right ordering and domeſtical prouiſion for houſeholde? And becauſe you ſhal wel vnderſtand, that he thinketh no thinge more princelyke then the maner of Tillage and Huſbandry, he entroduceth Socrates in that booke reaſoninge with Critobulus, Kinge Cyrus much delighted in Huſbandrye. and tellyng him, howe the noble and puiſſaunt Cyrus the ſecond of that name, kinge of Perſia, (a Prince not onelye conſpicuous and renowmed for his incomparable witte and pollicye, but alſo ſuch a one as had the regiment and ſoueraignetie ouer manye greate Realmes, & populous countreys) delighted
excetingly therin. For when as vpō a certain time a noble man of the countraie.Lyſander. Lacedemonia, called Lyſander came vnto him, then ſeiourning at his faire citie of Sardis & broughte to him from hys felowes in armes & confederates, diuers rich and honorable preſents, he not only in moſt amicable wiſe receiued & welcomed him, ſhewing to him al poinctes of princely courteſie in al other things generallye, but namelye in that, he ſhewed him a certain goodly field, hedged in and trimelye encloſed, ſet full of trées of all ſorts, moſt exquiſitely planted. Whiche when Lyſander had well viewed, & ſtedfaſtly a good while with an admiracion beheld, & had cōſidered both the height of the Trées, & the exacte order which was preciſely obſerued in ye placing & ſetting of them ſo equidiſtantly, that which way ſo euer a man caſt his eyes they ſtoode in a moſt perfect fourme of a Quincūcie, the ground ſo wel laboured & ſo pure of it ſelf withal, & the redolent ſmelles which the
ſwéete floures yelded: he ſpake vnto the king and ſaide: that he did not ſo muche muſe & meruayle at the diligence, handlyng and fine workemanſhippe, as he did at the promptitude of wit, the ſubtile arte, and the politike conuaighaunce of him that planted and ſet theym in ſuche perfecte meaſure and proporcion. Vnto whom Cyrus made this aunſwere: It is euen I (O Lyſander) and none other man, that haue made and by meaſure planted all theſe trées which thou ſéeſt, the order of the rowes wherein they ſtand, is my only deuyſe, this platte and deſeription I my ſelfe drew, and a great meignye of theſe trées wer graffed and planted with the labour of myne owne handes. Then Lyſander firing his eyes vpon the kings purple Robes and his riche attire, well noting the propre feacture of his comely bodye, the beautifull lineamentes and Symmetrie of his wel and portely compacte perſonage, together withe all the coſtlye apparaile wherein hee was after
the Perſian maner arayed, his garments powdred and fringed with much golde, precious ſtones, & Orient pearles whoſe value was ineſtimable, ſpake theſe wordes vnto him: Truly O Cyrus nowe doe I wel ſe, that it is not done without right good cauſe and conſideracion, that thou art bruyted abroad and reported in euery place to bee a happie and a fortunate Prynce,Virtuti fortuna comes. for vnto thy rare vertue and nobleneſſe, fortune alſo is conioyned and aſſociated. Therefore old men maye vſe and enioye this fortune, neither is their age any ſuch lette or obſtacle for theym, but that they may in al other thinges do ſemblablye, but moſt chiefly let vs embrace the huſbandmans life, and employ our ſelues to manure and til the ground euen vntyl the extreme and laſt point of our age. We haue hearde ſaye, that M. Valerius Coruinus liued tyll hee was an hundreth yeres old, and in the latter end of his old age, lyued in the Countraye, & gaue himſelfe to culture and huſbandry,
after he had bene ſixe times Conſul, and betwéene his firſt and his ſixte Couſulate there were xlvi yeares. Therefore that ſpace and time of yeares which our forefathers apointed and ment to be the beginning of old age, he ſo vigorouſlye ſuſtayned and ouercame, that hee was thought worthye to beare the higheſt offices and dygnityes in the Communs wealthe. And his extreme olde age was hearein more fortunate and bleſſed then hys myddle age, becauſe it was decorated with a great deale more honour and authorytie, and put to much leſſe paines and laboure. Nowe the higheſte title of prayſe that can be geuen to olde age is Authorytie. O what a noble magyſtrate was L. Cecilius Metellus? Authoritie the greateſte oruamēt, of old age what a worthie authoritie was there in Attilius Collatinus, in whoſe prayſe and commendacion many nacions with one voice & conſent gaue this honourable ſtile, to be called ye noble protectoure, the ſure Shielde, the truſty leanyng ſtaffe, and the ſtrong botreaux
of the Romaine people and their libertyes. The Epitaphe or Encomye yt was engrauen vpon his Tombe is wel knowen. Worthily therfore and by good right oughte he to be ſurnamed a graue honourable perſonage, of whom ſo good a report and fame, was generally blazed and teſtified by the mouthe of ſo manye men, withoute diſdaigne, enuye, heart-burning, or grudging of any. What a Iewel had we of late dayes of P. Craſſus when he was high prieſt? or of M. Lepidus who in ye ſame office ſucceded him? wherto ſhold I ſpeake of Paulus Aemilius, or Africanus or of Quintus Maximus (of whom I ſpake a lytle before) in whō, there was ſuche a portelye grace and Maieſtye, that not onelye in their wyſe and dyſcréete Counſayles, but alſo in theyr vyſages & lookes, yea and in their beckes there was euidentlye to be ſeene and deſcryed the true and lyuely Image of perfecte Aucthorytie? Olde age and ſpecyallye ſuche as is not contempned
nor deryded, but reuerenced and honoured, hath in it ſo greate aucthoritye, that it is muche more to bee eſteemed and is farre moore woorthe, then all the vaine pleaſures of headye and raſhe Adoleſcencye.What maner of olde age is to be Prayſed. But this I woulde require you to remembre, that in all this my talke, I doe prayſe that olde age, whoſe foundacion was layed and grounded in the yeares of youthe, and toke his firſte beginning at Adoleſcencie. Whervpon my old ſayinge (which in open audience I haue ſo often vſed to ſpeake, and wherevnto al men with one accord conſented) is verifyed, which was, that that old age which had no noble déedes to defende it ſelfe withal, but leaned onely to vaine iangling words & prating vauntes, was wretched & miſerable. It is not the hoare head, and wrinkled face which by and by bringeth honour and purchaſeth eſtimation, but it is an honeſte and godlye life that hath euer bene conuerſaunte and trayned in vertue which getteth dignity
and high aucthority in the end. For theſe things which ſéeme to be verie ſmal, are in déede very honourable: to be ſaluted, & deſired into the compaignie of honeſte men, to ſée manye men to goe aſyde and géeue the way where they ſhal paſſe, to be reuerenced, to be broughte and conducted home, to haue many wayters geuing attendaunce on theym, when they goe from home, to be ſued vnto for counſayle, and to be requeſted for their patronage & aduiſe in waighty and difficulte matters, whyche thinges bothe amonge vs and in al other wel gouerned and cyuile ordered Cities are moſt diligentlye and preciſely obſerued Lyſander a prince of Lacedemonia: (of whome I ſpake erewhile) is reported, that he woulde commonly ſay, that the moſt honeſte and fitteſt Manſion or Lodginge for old age to dwel and liue in, was in Lacedemonia: Great reuerence among ye Heathen ſhewed to olde age. for in no place els is ſo muche prerogatiue and reuerence ſhewed and géeuen to old age as ther, It is alſo conſecrated
to perpetual memorye and left in wryting, that a certain elderly man came on a time into the Theatre at Athens wher ſolemne Playes and pageauntes where exhibited to the people, where ther was not one man in the whole aſſemblye being his natural countrye men and felow Citeſins that ſhewed to him anye courteſie neither gaue to him anye roume to ſitte in and repooſe his weake and debilitated membres: but when hee came amonge Lacedemonians (who as it chaunced were at that tyme ther as Ambaſſadours and had their places in reſpect of their Ambaſſade accordinglye apoincted them) they al arooſe & place to him, inuiting and receyuyng hym among them to ſit in the eaſieſt & honourableſt ſeate. At which curteous vrbanitie of the Lacedemonians, when al the people in token of praiſe clapped their hands with many acclamatiōs gratulatory, one of ye Ambaſſadours brake out in theſe words & ſayd, yt ye Athenians knew wel what was honeſt
& vertuous, but to do it they would not. Many good orders are in our conſiſtorye or Colledge of Senatours, & namely this is one: for euery one according to his ſenioritie and elderſhyp in yeres, doth firſt pronounce his ſentence and vtter hys mynd. And the auncient and aged Augurs are eſtéemed and preferred not only before right honourable maieſtrats which beare rule & office, but alſo before them, that haue the chiefe regiment and ſoueraigne rule in the cōmon wealth. Therfore what corporal pleaſures are comparable with theſe rewards and aduauncements of authority? wherein whoſoeuer gloriouſlye haue behaued theymſelues, they in mine opynion haue moſt worthely & comendably played the pageaunte of ye whole diſcourſe of their age,Theſe are the vices of maners & not of old age. & not like dranelike & idle ſtage players in the laſt act of al, geuē ouer & quailed. But many old mē be waiward, il to pleaſe, lowring, comberous, fretting & chafing, whining & in exporable, and (if we throughly ſifte
out the matter) myſerable nygardes and penchpentes alſo: but al theſe are not the faultes peculier to old age, but incident to them whoſe naughty maners be ſubfect & diſpoſed therunto. But their waywardnes and other faultes (which I before rehearced) may alledge and pretend a ſmall pretext of excuſation, whiche althoughe it be not true, yet it is ſuch as in apparaunce ſéemeth to be probable. For they thinke theymſelues to bee contemned, flowted, vnregarded and deryded.

Furthermore in a weake & ſore worne body. (ſuch as old men haue) euery ſmal offence is odious and ſéemeth to theym diſpleaſunt: al which faultes neuertheleſſe through good maners and diſcipline are condulcate, qualefied & made ſwete, which thing to be true, may wel be perceyued bothe by the common courſe of mens lyuing, and alſo by the Comedy of Terence entytuled Adelphi, where he induceth two brethren of contrarye diſpoſition, inclinacion and maners, and the
one his nature in all poinctes varyinge and ſwaruinge from the others. What ruſtical behauioure and cloyniſhe bluntnes is in the one? Againe, what courteous vrbanitie, what honeſt demeanoure, what ciuil faſſhions, what affability and what lenitie is in the other? So ſtandeth the matter, and ſo by dayly experience is it to be ſene. For euen as euery wyne being old and ſtanding long is not conuerted into vineigre: ſo likewiſe is not euery age, ſower, eigre and vnpleaſaunt.Meaſurable ſeueritie all owable in an old man. Seuerity and ſterneneſſe in old age I well allow and commend, ſo that a moderate meane therin (as in al other thinges) be obſerued, but bitterneſſe and rigorous dealinge I can in no wyſe brooke nor away withall.Nothing ſtandeth more againſte reaſon, then for an old ma to be couctous. But as for the avarice and couetouſnes of old menne, I am not acquainted therwith, neither doe I knowe what it meaneth. For what can be more abſurde or repugnaunt to al reaſon, thē for a wayfaring man when his iourney is now almoſt diſpatched and brought to
an ende and hath but litle way to goe, to prouyde and furniſhe him ſelfe with the more victualles, and the ſhorter that his iourneye is, the more to ſéeke and purueigh for coſtage?

The fourth cauſe, whyche moſte of all greueth & diſquieteth old men, remaineth yet behind vndiſcuſſed, which is the approching of death, & the néereneſſe therof, which truly can not be farre of frome olde age. O miſerable and wretched olde caitife, if in ſee longe a time as hee hath lyued, hée hathe not perceaued and learned, that deathe is vtterlye to bee contemned and not at all to bee feared:Deathe not to bee feared. whiche were either flatlye to bee deſpyſed if it didde vtterlye kyll and ſlea the mynde, that nothinge afterward ſhoulde remayne: or els is greatlye to be deſyred if it bée the inſtrumente and gate wherby the ſame mynde or ſoule paſſeth and is caryed into blyſſe, for euermore wyth immortall and euerlaſtynge felycitye to bee eternized. Certes there canne no
no thirde or meane be founde. Therfore what ſhould I feare, if after death I ſhal bee eyther not myſerable, or els bleſſed? notwithſt andynge who is hée that hath ſoe ſmall reaſon and wytte, to auouche and awarraunt hymſelfe (althoughe hee were neuer ſo luſtie) that he ſhall lyue tyl the nexte eueninge?Youth more ſubiecte to ſickeneſſe then age. Yea I ſay this further, younge menne are ſubiecte to moe occaſyons of deathe, (becauſe of the humours and bloude which do abounde in theym, and are the nouriſſhers of the matter of Maladyes and dyſeaſes. They fall ſooner into ſickeneſſe, and infirmityes, their dyſeaſes are more peryllous and vehemente, theyr recouerye and cure more dyfficile. And therefore there are but féewe that lyue tyll they come to Olde age, whyche if it weare not ſo, but that there myght be a great number of old menne, they woulde liue a greate deale more pleaſauntlye and wyſely.

For wytte, reaſon and good counſayle reſteth in olde menne, and therefore if
there were no olde men,Comon weelthes and cities beſie gouerned by auncicient mē. there woulde conſequently bee no Cityes. But I will leaue theſe digreſſions or byreckenings, and conuert my talke to ſpeake of imminent death. Is this any euil or fault that can be laied to old age, ſithens you dayly ſée the ſame to belong and be commune aſwell to Adoleſcencie?Deathe ſparethe no age. I my ſelfe haue had good proofe and felt the heauy experience, not only by the immature deathe of my worthy and louing Sonne, but alſo of thy brethren, Scipio, (of whome the Romaines for their noble towardneſſe, had conceyued a great hope to ſee theim aduaunced to moſt ample and high dignityes) that death is common to all age, both young and old indifferently. But a younge man hopeth to liue long, which an old man may not looke to do. He trulye féedeth him ſelfe with a vaine and a fooliſhe hope. For what méerer folly can there be, thenne to accompte and repute things which be doubtful & vncertaine, for infallible and certaine, and thinges
that are falſe, for true? An old man hath nothing to hope for: but he is therfore in farre better ſtate and caſe,The olde man is in better ſtate thē the yong man is. then is a yong man, for he hath already enioyed and obtayned that, whych the younge man doth but hope for. The one deſireth to lyue long, the other hath already liued long: albeit (O Lorde) what is in mans life, that may be ſayd to be long and of anye diuturnitye. Admitte we liue til extreme old age: let vs hope and thinke that wée ſhal lyue as long as euer dyd the king of Tarteſsians.
Argantonius lyued. 120. yeyeares. His name (as I find in hiſtoryes) was Argantonius, who in the Iſles called Gades in ye furtheſt parts of Spaine rayned lxxx. yeares and liued a hundreth and twentye. But to me there ſeemeth nothing long, wherein anye extréeme or end is: for when that ende or extreme is once come, then al which is already paſt, is quight gone, and nothing remayneth but onely that which a man hath by vertue atchieued, and by good déedes & workes perpetrated. For houres goe awaye
apace, ſo doe dayees, monethes and yeares, and the tyme whiche is once ſlipte by, and gone, neuer retourneth, neyther can the tymes and things whych are to come, be preciſelye knowen. Therefore euerye one ought to be contented wyth the ſpace & tyme, whych god graunteth him to liue. For he that is a Stageplaier néedeth not of neceſſitye to bee an Actor in the Enterlude or Comody tyl the laſt end thereof, (to delyghte the beholders) but in what acte of the ſame ſo euer hée playeth or chaunceth to bée, he muſte ſo expreſſelye handle and playe his parte, that hée maye wynne prayſe and commendacion: neyther ſhoulde a wyſeman liue tyll the Plaudite be ſtryken vp. For a ſhorte ſpace and tyme of lyfe, is longe ynoughe to lyue well and honeſtly, and in whatſoeuer age we bee in, it is ſufficyente to haue lyued therein godlye and vertuouſlye. But if you procéede further, and lyue to extremytye of age, you muſte not bée diſcontented nor aggréeued
ther with, no more thenne Huſbandemen doe, to ſée after a pleaſaunte and temperate Springe ſeaſonne, Sommer and Autumne to ſuccéede. For the Springe tyme reſembleth and is like to Adoleſcencye, dyſplayinge and playnlye ſhewynge what fruyctes wyll growe: all the other tymes and ſeaſons ſerue to reape, mowe, cutte downe, gather, gleane, and receyue theym into the barnes.The fruictes of olde age. Nowe, the fruicte of Olde age (as I ſayde before) is a pure and vpryghte Conſcience, and the good teſtimonye or witneſſe that a mans owne mynde beareth, of the vertuous and irrepreh euſible lyfe, decentlye and inculpable ledde.

For all thinges whiche come by courſe of Nature are to bee reckened and accompted among good things: and what is ſooe muche accordynge to naturall courſe, as for an Olde aged manne to dye? Whych doothe happen to younge men, as it were Maugre Natures good wyll. Therefore younge men in myne
opynyon ſéeme ſo to dye,Youngmē ſtruggle for bitterneſſe of paine in dying but olde men die, lyke the going oure of a Candle. as when a raging and violente flame of fyre isquenched, withe a greate quantytye or effuſion of water: but old men dye, as it wer, fyer, which lacking woode and combuſtible matter to nouriſhe it, goeth out quietly, and is quenched, as though it were of his owne accord, not forciblye. And as Apples which are gréene and vuripe, are not plucked from the Trée but by a certaine violent plucking, but if they be ripe and mellow, they fal voluntarily downe from the Trée: So lyke wyſe, yongemen depart out of their life by violent force & painful ſtruggelyng, but old men dye by a certayne rypenes and maturitye. And as often as I thinke thereon, I am rapt with ſuch ioy and coumfort, that the néerer I draw & approch to death, the ſoner me thinke, I ſée the dry land, & (as it wer after a long Nauigacion and Seafaring voyage) ſhal at length arriue at the quiet hauen and Port of all reſt and ſecuritye. All other ages haue a certayne number
of yeares apointed, how long euery one continueth, but vnto old age ther are no determinate and certayne tymes limitted and prefixed, and therefore thou lyueſt ther in well and laudablye, as long as thou cāſt execute thy office, dyſcharge thy dutye, and defend thyne aucthoritye, & yet neuertheleſſe to contempne death. And for this cauſe, it happeneth, that old age is endued with greater courage and animoſitie, then Adoleſlencie and youth is. And this is the cauſe, that when the Tyraunt Pyliſtratus demaunded of Solon how he durſt be ſo bold, or wherin he repoſed his truſt, ſo wilfully and boldly to again ſay & diſobaie his Procedings: Solon Aunſwered him that he truſted to his Old age, and that was it, that made him ful of Courage, and gaue him boldnes to reſiſt him: for as much as he with lawleſſe force and monſtruons tyranny had attempted to oppreſſe the Common wealth, myſerably fruſſhed through his vnbrydeled and tyrannycall inuaſions.

But the beſte ende of life is this: when nature which compacted and framed the body, doth like wyſe diſſolue and bringe to deathe the ſame, beinge in good and perfecte remembraunce, the vſe of the wittes and ſenſes in no parte appayred nor dimininiſſhed. For euen as ye Shipwrighte, whiche made the Shippe, knoweth beſte howe to vndoe and pulle the ſame aſundre againe, and as none hath better ſkill to vnioynte or take downe a houſe, then the Carpēter that made it: euen ſo nature, which faſſhioned ye feacture of the body & ſet the ſame in a moſt decent Symmetrie, doth beſte diſſolue & end it by natural death. For euerye conglutinacion when it is freſh and newly glewed together, wil not eaſily be pulled a ſundre but by violent haling and forcible rupture, but when it is inueterate & old, it may eaſilye be diuelled & ſeuered. Thus you ſée, that the ſmall remanent and time of oure race and lyfe whyche is behinde vnrunne, is neyther affectuouſly
to be deſired, nor without cauſe to bee lefte and forſaken. And the famous Philoſopher Pythagoras, This life is but a warfare. géeueth vs a ſore charge, that we ſhould not departe oute of the garriſon and wardehouſe of this life, vnleſſe we haue commiſſion & commaundement from our general captaine whiche is GOD. Solon hys wiſe ſaying is verye notable and praiſe worthye, for hee woulde not that his deathe ſhould be vnbewayled and vnlamented of his friends. His meanyng (I thinke) was, becauſe he would not ſeeme to be forgotten, but rather entierly to bee beloued & remembred of his frends, which thinge their dolourous plaintes and inward griefes at his laſt end and funeral obſequies ſhold bewray & euidently witneſſe. But yet Ennius his opinion in like caſe, may in my iudgement be better allowed, for he woulde not haue his friendes to moane and lamente for him after his deathe, and theſe are hys wordes.

q.l: Surceaſſe from teares, when I am dead,
And let not them for me be ſheadde.
VVhen death ſhall with his deadly darte,
My Corps and Soule aſundre part.
And why? the clanging trumpe of fame
Shall euer ſounde abroade my name.

sp.p:
This noble Poete woulde not haue the deathe of theym to be lamented and with feminine blubbering & ſchrietches to be bewayled, whoſe praiſe and vertue is immortalized and enrolled in the boke of fame, & their worthy déedes regiſtred in the ſcroll of eternity. As touching the bitter panges and extreame agonyes whyche they ſuffer that lye in dyinge, (if there may any ſuch be) trulye it continueth but for a ſmal while, ſpeciallye in an old man: and after death, the ſence is eyther ſuch as is bleſſed and optable, or els it is none at al. But al yong men ought to imprint this in their myndes, and meditate the ſame, that they be not in anye ſeruyle and daſtardlye feare of death, but
to ſtand at defiaunce and contempne it.Hee that ſtandethe in feare of death, cannot be quiet in mynd. For whoſoeuer envreth not him ſelfe with this meditation, cā not haue a quiet mynd. We are moſt ſure that we muſte dye, & we know not whether oure houre will come euen that ſame verye daye. Therfore he that euerye houre ſtandeth in feare of death,Nothing more certain then death, nothinge more vncertaine then the houre of death. how can hys mynd bee in any reſt or tranquilitye. Wher of ther néedeth no very long diſputacion to bée had, ſith I do wel remembre not onelye L. Brutus, whoe in the quarrell of his Countrye whyche was deſpoyled and wyth tyrannye oppreſſed,Valiaūte knightes whiche dyed for ſauegard of the countrie. moſt manfully was ſlaine: the two Decij, who being armed at al pieces & mounted on horſeback galloped and gaue them ſelues willingly to death for their Countrie ſake: M. Regulus, who (rather then he would forſweare him ſelfe, and breake promyſe wyth hys moſt deadly and bloudy Enemyes) went wyllyngly to his moſte certayne torment and puniſhment (wher he wel knew that he ſhould ſuffer death after
a ſtraunge and terreble maner) and would not in any wiſe by his kinſfolkes and friends be altered and remoued frō his determinacion: The twoe Scipioes, who with their owne bodyes choiſe rather to ſtoppe the paſſage of the freſhe ſuccours (whiche vnder the conducte of Haſdrubal, came to ayde Hanniball and the proude Carthaginians, ſore infeſting & afflicting Italye with ſweard, famine, and fyre) then to ſuffer and permit them, to ſet any foote within the territories & Precinctes of the Romaine dition: your Graundfather L. Paulus, who throughe the temeritie and folye of his fellowe in office Terentius Varro, was in that ignominious ouerthrowe and ſhameful dyſcomfiture, in the conflict and battaile of Cannas, ſlaine and brought to confuſion: and M. Marcellus, whoſe valiaunce and magnanimitie was ſo great and ſo weil tryed, that his & our moſt cruel ennemye Hannibal, when he hadde ſlaine him in the field, cauſed his dead corſe with all
funeral pompe and ſolemnitie of ſepulture to be enterred: but alſo how our legions and Armyes, couragiouſly aduentured to take ſuch voyages, & venturous expeditions into ſuch daūgerous places, frō whence they loked to retourne aliue again, wherof I haue wrytē in my booke of Originalles. Shal therefore olde men whych haue great knowledge & experience feare that, which yong ſtriplings & the ſame not only vnſkilful but alſo blūt and ruſtical do contemne & care not for? But me thinke, ſocietie of al things, can ſeth ſo ciety of life.Euerye age hathe his peculier delite & ſtudye. Ther are ſome phantaſticall and childyſhe playes whereat youge children in their childhode delight to playe: ſhal therfore yong men and tall felowes addicte them ſelues to the ſame ſemblablie? There are ſome exerciſes & affections wherein youthly yeares doe envre them ſelues: ſhall the rype & conſtant age (whych is called ye myddle age of manne) looke to playe at the ſame? And of this myddle age, there are ſome
ſtudyes, willes and appetites, whyche old age careth not for. And ther be ſome ſtudies and exerciſes belonging and appropriate to old age. And therfore as the pleaſure and delite of the ſtudies and exerciſes in freſſher and luſtier ages dothe in time were away and come to an end, ſo dothe the ſtudyes of olde age in continuaunce and tract of time alſo dye and vaniſh. And when this pleaſure and delightfull contentacions begynne in olde men once to decreaſe, then doth ſacietye of life bring to theym a conuenable and mature tyme to dye. For verily I cannot ſe, why I ſhoulde not be bolde to vtter and declare to you twaine, the verye entier cogitacions of my hart, and the opinion which I haue of death: and the rather, becauſe I ſuppoſe that I do better knowe and ſée it, as one, that nowe am neere the pittes brinke, hauinge one of my féete already in the graue. And I am in this beléefe (O P. Scipio and C. Laelie) that your noble fathers, menne for their
vertuous maners and worthy demerites immortalized, who alſo weare my moſte deare and louing friends, do yet liue, yea and ſuch a life, as is worthye only to bée called a lyfe, which is immortall and not tranſitory. For ſo long as wée dwel and be included within this lumpiſh body proportioned with ioyntes, ſynewes, fleſhe, bone, and other partes,The body is the pryſon or caſe of ye ſoule. whiche maye bee called the pryſō or caſe of our Soule, we are dryuen & by a neceſſitie enforced to do ſome actions (wil we or nill we) as to ſlepe, eate, drinke &c: and to do ſom cumbreſome workes whiche are ineuitable. But the minde or ſoule which is diuine and celeſtiall, ſent downe from god oute of Heauen and infuſed into man, is depreſſed and as it were, forciblye deiected or thruſte downe to the earthe, beinge a place quighte contrarie to diuine nature and e • ternitye, becauſe it is mortall and viſible wherof ye other is immortal & inuiſible.Note the opinion of a Heathen. But I do thinke, that the immortal Gods inſpired myndes into humaine
bodyes, becauſe ther ſhould be ſome to inhabite ye earth, who beholdyng & conſidering the orders of ye celeſtial bodies, & waighing how duelie they obſerue their courſes and motions, might imitate and folow the ſame right order in the trades of their life and conſtancy. And not only reaſon and frequent diſputacion moueth me thus to beleue, but alſo the profoūde doctrine and authorities of moſt noble & approued Philoſophers. For I haue ben in place, where I harde that Pythagoras and his diſciples which inhabiied within our countrey and were in maner frée Denizons within our precincte and dominion (for they wer once named Italian Philoſophers) affirmed and ſaid, that they weare neuer otherwyſe perſwaded nor neuer helde opinion to the contrarie, but that our mindes were fourmed and deriued from the vniuerſal diuinity of god. Furthermore it was tolde me, what Socrates diſputed and ſpake concerning the immortalitye of the ſoule, and what hée
openly ſayd beinge an auncient philoſopher and one, whom Apollo his Oracle iudged the wiſeſt man in ye whole world, euen the laſt day of his life, a litle before his death. What néedeth many wordes? I am ſo firmelye perſwaded and on thys poinct ſo whollye reſolued, ſeinge there is ſo great celeritie of the mynde, ſo good remembraunce of thinges paſte, and ſo great forcaſt and prudeuce in thinges to come, ſo many Artes, ſo many Sciences, ſo many inuentions & ingenious deuiſes, that the nature whiche vnderſtandeth & contayneth ye knowledge of al theſe things is not mortal.The immortality of the ſoule proued. And ſith ye mind is euer moued, hauing no beginning of mocion becauſe it moueth it ſelfe, & ſhall neuer haue any end of mocion, becauſe it is eternal, & ſhal neuer leaue it ſelf: and ſith the nature of the mind is ſimple, hauing nothing mixed to it which is vnlike and diſcrepant to it, I therby know, that it is indiuiſible, wherevpon it conſequentlye followethe, that for as muche as it is
diuiſible, it can neuer do & periſh vtterly. And theſe reaſōs folowing make much for the probacion therof, that men know many thinges before they be borne, that Children (notwithſtanding the abſtruſe and painfull difficultie of Artes) doe ſo quicklye learne and as who would ſaye, ſnatchingly conceiue innumerable thinges, that they ſéeme, not than at the fyrſt to learne them, but rather repete and cal them againe to memorye. Theſe bee for the moſt parte the argumentes and reaſons which the dyuine philoſopher Plato alledgeth and bringeth for his proufe of the immortalitye of the ſoules. Alſo Xenephon writethe, that Kinge Cyrus the elder lyinge on his deathe bedde, ſpake theſe words folowing to his children:Lib. 8. de paed. Cy. I would not (my children) that you ſhould thinke, when I am departed out of this life and goone frome you, that I ſhal be no wher or brought to nothyng. For you neuer ſawe with your bodilye eyes, my mynde, duringe all this whyle
that I lyued here with you: but as long as I dwelled in this bodye, you wel perceyued and knewe by my valyaunte exploytes and actes, that I hadde a minde. Therfore thinke you not otherwiſe, but that I am the very ſame ſtil, and my ſaid mynde ſhall ſtill remayne as before, althoughe you ſée it not viſiblie. For neyther ſhoulde the noble memoriall and honourable Monumentes of Princes & worthy Perſonages remaine after their death, if in their life time, by the pollicie and proweſſe of their minds, they did not atchieue ſome worthy enterpiſes, wherby their fame and honoure might be remembred and magnifyed of their poſterity. Truly it would neuer ſincke in my braine that the minds or ſoules did liue onelye whyle they remayned in mortall bodyes, and beyng departed out of them vtterly to dy, that no more of them ſhold remaine. Nor that the ſoule and mynd of ſottes and fooles is doltiſh and blockiſhe
whenne it is ſette at libertye and departed oute of their foolyſhe Bodyes: but whenne it is puryfyed frome the fylthye admixtion and droſſie impurytye of the ſame bodye, and fyned frome imperfection and beginning to be ſounde, perfect and cleare, thenne is it wyſe, ſapiente and incorrupte.

And Mannes nature beynge by death diſſolued, it is apparaunte and well ynoughe to all menne knowen, to what place all the other partes doe goe: for they dooe all retourne to that matter, whereof they hadde theyr fyrſt and Oryginall beginninge: but the mynd onelye is neuer wythe anye bodylye eyes ſéene nor perceyued, neyther when it is in the Bodye nor whenne it goeth and departeth oute of the bodye.

Nowe, you ſee that nothinge is ſoe like to deathe as Sleape. And yet the myndes of them that are a ſleape do greatly declare their diuinitie: for whenne they
be at quietneſſe & reſt & wyth no careful cogitations ouerwhelmed, they doe forſée mannye thinges to come, wheareby it may playnlye be perceyued, howe and in what happy ſtate they ſhall be, when they bee diſmiſſed and diſcharged oute of theyr dungeon or gaole of theyr mortall Bodyes. Yf therefore theſe thinges bée true, then reuerence and honour me as a Godde, for the participacion of the dyuyne Nature whyche is in my mynde. But if the Soule doe dye together wythe the bodye (as ſome aſſeheaded Phyloſophers, flatterynge theym ſelues in theyr beſtyall lyuynge and wallowynge lyke Swyne in the fylthye puddle of theyr Epycuriall ſenſualyty haue affyrmed) yet you euer dreadynge the Goddes, beinge the Protectours, dyſpoſers, and gouernours of all the beautyfull ornamente and furnyture of thys wydde woorlde ſhall not myſſe but Godlye and inuyolablye ſolemnyze
and kepethe memorial of me. Theſe aduertiſementes and exhortacions Cyrus gaue to his ſonnes lyinge on his death bed. Now let vs (if you thinke good) take a ſuruay of our owne ſelues, and ſée wheather the ſame opynion and beléefe be not to bee founde in vs and in other of our countraimen. I wil be plain which thée, Scipio: no man in the worlde ſhall euer be able to perſwade me, that either thy father Paulus Aemilius, or thy two Graund fathers Paulus and Africanus, or P. Scipio the brother of Aphricanus, or C. Scipio his vncle, or many moe famous and worthye men, whiche here néede not to bee rehearſed, woulde euer haue attempted ſuch perillous aduentures (onely to leaue a noble and worthye memoriall of their fame and valiaunce to their ſequele, whō they wiſſhed ſhold take example of their fortitude, & treade in the footeſteppes of their laudable vertues wherby they myghte atchieue like ſucceſſe in their glorious affayres and
not feare to dye in the quarrell of their countrie whē foraine hoſtilitie inuadeth it) if with the quicke vnderſtandynge of their myndes they had not wel ſéene and conſidered that theyr poſteritye appertayned and belonged to theym, Doe you thinke that I (for I may I truſte, ſomewhat vaunt and boaſt of my ſelfe as olde men are wont to doe) woulde euer haue vndertaken ſo many laboures and painfull trauailes night and day, both in the time of peace and alſo of warre, if I had had this opinion fixed and rooted in my mynd, that my glorye and fame ſhoulde extend no further then my natural lyfe, and that when the one ceaſſed the other ſhould dye alſo? for if that were ſo, were it not (I pray you) a great deale better to leade a quiet life ſequeſtred and exempt from all hurlye burlie and toylinge buſineſſe, and neuer to entermedle wythe contentious matters, and the laborious affaires of the weale publique? But the mynd of noble perſonages (I know not
how it chaūceth) erecting it ſelf & taking courage, had euer ſuch a careful reſpecte to their ſucceſſion, as though when they wer departed out of this lyfe, they ſhold then at length & neuer tyll then liue and flouriſh, their incomparable geſtes triū phing ouer cancard obliuion & their vertuous liues ouer mortal deathe. For if it wer not ſo, that ye ſoules ſhold be immortal, the mynd of euerye good & vertuous man would not ſo earneſtly wyth al his ſtudy & deuoireſeke to attaine and aſpire to immortal glory & perpetual renowne Furthermore,The godly deſyre death but the vngodlye ſeare it. euery good and wiſe man dieth willingly, and reioyceth therin excedingly, taking death to be a ioyful meſſenger to ſomon him to endleſſe felicitie: on the other ſyde, euerye foolyſhe man dyeth vnwillinglie. Do you not thinke, that that minde whiche ſéeth better and further of, doth well perceiue and know that he goeth to a farre better ſtate then in this worlde is to be founde? Agayne, the mynd of the fooliſhe ſort whoſe ſight
is dimmer and duller doothe not ſée nor vnderſtand ſo much? But verily I haue a great deſire to ſee and beholde your fathers, whom I entyrelye loued and had for their ſinguler vertues in great admiracion. And not them onely am I ſoe earneſtlye affected to ſee, with whome I was verye familierly acquainted, but others alſo, of whō I haue both hard,This place is tranſlated accordinge to two ſundrye Latine textes of diuerſe printes. read & alſo writē. And whē I am in my iorney to them (which I ſo greatly deſire) ther ſhold no mā bring me back again, though he would & alſo cold: neither to make me to retire to the place from whēce I came, like to a bal, which Tenyſeplayers toſſe & ſtrike to their counterplayers, & they again to ye otherſide, yea though he would vndertade to runne my youth againe, as we read that Pelias was in his old age. I wil ſay more, if god wouldgraūt me now in this age to retorne again to my infancie and to be as yonge as a child that lyeth crying in his cradle I woulde refuſe & forſake the offer with all my mighte:
neyther would I when I haue alreadye in a manner runne the whole race and wonne the gole, be again reuoked from the ende markes, to the Liſtes or place where I toke my courſe at the firſt ſetting out. For who would be contented, when he hath gotten the beſte game to bee forced to runne againe for the ſame? What pleaſure and commoditye hathe lyfe? yea rather, what paine, toile and labour hath it not? But let vs admit that it had great commodyty, yet vndoubtedly, it hath eyther an ende or els ſacietye. For I meane not to lament and deplore the lacke of the pleaſaunt and freſh time of my youthe, as diuerſe and the ſame right well learned men haue done, neyther doe I repente, that I haue lyued, becauſe I haue ſo lyued and ledde my life, that I maye iudge of my ſelf, that I was not borne in vaine,This life is but a Pylgrymage. but rather for greate vtilitye and ſpecyall conſideracion. And I departe oute of this lyfe, as out of an Inne and not out of a dwellynge
houſe. For nature hath géeuen to vs a lodginge to remayne and ſeiourne in for a tyme, and not to dwell in continually. O lucky and bleſſed day, wherin I ſhall take my iourneye to appeare before that bliſful troupe and conuocation of happye myndes, and leaue this troubleſome world, being the vaile of al miſery and the filthy ſinck of al myſchiefe. For I ſhal not onelye goe to thoſe worthie men (of whō I ſpake a litle before) but alſo to my deare ſonne Cato; whoe was a man of ſuche ſanctitie and goodnes, as none more, of ſuch ſyncere & vnſtayned honeſtye, as none better, whoſe bodye was wyth funerall rites putte into the fyer and bourned to aſhes by me his father, whereas it hadde béene more méete and more agrée able to the courſe of nature, that my Bodye ſhoulde haue béene wythe ſemblable obſequeys and Ceremonyes fyrſte burnte and intumulate by him. But hys mynde and Soule not vtterlye forſakyng mée, but euer lookynge
and expectinge my commynge, is gone before into thoſe places of ioye, whither he perceyued that I my ſelf (ere. it be long) muſt alſo come. Which brunt of calamytie and heauie chaunce of ſorow, I ſéemed paciently to ſuſtaine: not becauſe I did take the matter ſo pacientlye in déede, but I comforted my ſelfe, thinking and déeminge that we ſhoulde not be long a ſundre, but after a time againe to haue a ioyful méeting. Theſe are the cauſes and the very reaſons Scipio, (becauſe you and Laelius ſayde you much meruayled therat) which make my old age to me eaſie and tolerable, and not only without al greuaunce and diſturbation, but alſo repleniſhed wythall expediente pleaſures. And if I doe erre, becauſe I thinke that the ſoules of menne bée immortall, verilye I am well contented in the ſame erroure ſtyll to continue, and as longe as I lyue, I wyll neuer renounce nor recante the ſame, wherein I take ſuche ſinguler pleaſure
and coumfort: and if it were ſoe, that after deathe I ſhoulde féele nothinge nor haue no ſenſe at all, (as certaine Petyfoggers and baſtarde Phyloſophers hold opinion) I feare not a whitte, leaſt theſe lippelabourers and Idioticall Phyloſophers whenne they theym ſelues bee deade, ſhoulde ſkoffe and make a mockynge ſtocke at this myne aſſertion and beléefe, becauſe they theym ſelues ſhall alſo bee wythout ſenſe and lyke to bruit beaſtes. But admitte, that after deathe wée ſhoulde not bée immortall, yet is it boothe conuenyente and alſo optable for a manne, whenne hée hath honeſtly played his parte in the pageaunt of this lyfe to dye and pay hys debte to Nature. For Nature as ſhee hath an ende of all other thynges, ſoe alſo of lyuinge. And olde age is as it weare the peroration or finall end of a mans time in this world, much like to the Epilogue or Cathaſtrophe of an Enterlude: the weariſome repeticion or deſatigatiō wherof we ought
to auoyde and eſchewe, and eſpeciallye when we are fullye cloyed wythe ſacietye. Thus muche at youre requeſte I had to ſaye concernynge Olde age: vnto the whyche, God graunte you maye arryue, that the thinges whiche you haue hearde of mée by mouthe, you maye proue true by certayne tryall and actual experiment.

div.head: A briefe abſtract of yeares.
div.p:
I Thought I might verye well in this place annexe this Catalogue or Recital of ſuch Sages and honourable perſonages as lyued long: aſwel for the ſimilitude and affinitye of the Argumente, as for the admiration and coumfortable readinge wyth pleaſure of the thinge it ſelfe: ſythence in theſe oure dayes beinge in the laſte age of the worlde, not one amonge tenne thouſand lyueth the tenth part of their flouriſſhing time & auncientie: vnleſſe peraduenture there bee ſome that wil ſay (whoſe wordes I can not denye haue ſome couloure of probabilitie) that the yeares in old tyme were not ſo long, as our yeares now a dayes are, and that euery Nacion reckened after their countrayes familier computacion. For whoſe ſatiſfaction, I wil ſhew the difference of diuerſe yeares, firſt of theſe ſundry yeares that yet are allowed, and then of certaine
particuler yeares appropriate to ſundrye countraies and cities, and laſtly the authorities and minds of ſome learned men, concerning the compariſon of oure yeare and theirs together. Firſt it is to be conſidered, that there be iii. maner of yeares. One is named Annus Magnus, Annus Mundanus, or Annus Platonicus, contayning of our yeares (as not onlye Plato, but alſo Macrobius and Ioannes de ſacro Buſto do affirme) fiftene Thouſand yeres: in which time & ſpace, the Sunne with all the other planetes & fixed ſtarres of the firmament, retourne to the verye ſame poynctes and places, that they had at the firſt beginning. Ioſephus in the eyghte chapter of his fyrſte booke of Antiquities ſaieth it containeth but ſixe hundreth yeres. The ſeconde is called Annus Solaris, which is the ſpace wherin the Sunne completely finiſheth hys courſe throughe euerye ſigne of the Zodiacke, and retourneth againe to the ſame poincte whence it ſet out, which is
in 365. dayes, vi. houres and 8. minutes of an houre. Theſe vi. houres collected & ſet together do in foure yere amounte to xxiiii. houres, yt ſpace of an natural daye. And this is the cauſe, why euery fourth yere (to kepe the yere at a certaine ſtaye) we haue leape yeare, and that yere, Februarye hathe xxix. dayes and the yeare thre hundreth ſixtie and ſixe dayes. The odde eight minuts muſt be alſo diligently loked vnto, for els in proceſſe and tract of tyme it will cauſe greate erroure and confuſion. For in 120. yeares they do amount to a natural daye: Which beinge not obſerued, cauſeth the two Solſtitia, ye Aeſtiuall and the Hyemal, that is to ſay in playner woordes, when the dayes are at the longeſt, and when they bee at the ſhorteſt, and alſo the two Aequinoctia, that is, when they daye and nighte are of one lengthe to goe one daye backe, whyche woulde in tyme, if it bee not amended, make Chriſtmas (whiche is alreadye gone frome his iuſte time at the
begynnyng almoſt xv dayes) to be in the Spring, & Midſomer to be in Autumne, and al the feaſtes and tymes of the yere to a prepoſterous order. The thirde is Annus Lunaris whiche contayneth the ſpace of a mouthe. Furthermore, Romulus the firſt king of Rome, who liued ſeuen hundreth and thirtye yeares before chriſt, of whom the citye of Rome was both buylded and named deuyſed a yere that contained but tenne monthes, wher of Marche was the firſt in honour of his father Mars, then Aprill, then May, then Iune, then Quintilis, ſo named of the order that it had, becauſe it was the fyfte, thenne Sextilis becauſe it was the ſixte, which two names were afterward altered, and called, the one Iulye and the other Auguſte in honoure of Iulius Caeſar, and Octauius Auguſtus the firſt Emperours of Rome, then September, and ſo foorth to October-Nouember, and laſt of al December being the tenth. After the death of Romulus, Numa Pompilius ſurcéeded
in the kingedome, whoo added Ianuarye and Februarye to make the yeare of xii. monthes, and after the imitation of the Aegiptians, allotted to one monthe xxx. dayes, and to an other xxix, ſo that his yere had but thrée hundreth, fiftye, and foure dayes, whiche number agréeth not to the courſe of the Sunne. Laſte of all came Iulius Caeſar who eſpyinge the incouneniences, and erroures aforeſayde, added xi. dayes and ſixe houres, ſoe that thenne the yeare contayned three hundreth ſixty fiue dayes and ſixe houres, whiche yeare we euer ſince haue & do obſerue. Thus the other ſhott at the marke, but thys Iulius by helpe of one Soſigenes, hytte the pricke wythein verye lytle, as before I noted. Some countrayes rekened the yeare by noone of theſe wayes, but vſed an other pryuate maner. The Carians and the Acarnanians fyniſhed their yere in vi. months as Macrobius affyrmeth lib. 1 Saturnall.
The Arcadians (as Plutarch ſayth) made their yeare to be iii. monethes. The reſt of the Gréekes ended the yeare in 354 dayes. The Aegiptians as Solinus wryteth) had iiii. moneths to their yere, but the oldeſt and auncienteſt yere amonge them (as Cenſorinus ſayth) was but two moneths. Notwithſtādyng the Authorityes of theſe two famous wryters, Macrobius and Herodotus affyrme, that the certaine order and ſtay of the yeare alwayes was amonge them onely. Some countrayes accompted the Sommer for one yeare, and the winter for an other.

And as in yeres, ſo lykewiſe in the computation of dayes lyke diuerſitie is to be founde. For the Babilonians reckened a daye, the ſpace betwene the two Sunne riſinges. The Vmbrians from none tyll none. The Athenians betwene the two Sunne ſettings, Amonge the commune people a day is taken for the ſpace béetwene morning and night. Some kynde of dayes are called naturall, and ſome
Artificial. The natural daye is the ſpace of xxiiii. houres, reckening the night and the daye together. An Artificall daye is from the Sunne riſinge, till the Sunne going downe. The Clergie and Romaniſtes, the Aegiptians, Hipparchus the Philoſopher, apoinct a daye, from mydnight to mydnighte. The Aſtronomers from none to noone. Nowe to aunſwere ſuch as can vneth béeleue that Mathuſalem and others liued ſo manye of ſuch yeares as nowe wee vſe, truth it is, that the yeres then, were neither of a monthe nor yet of thrée monthes longe, which, hereby we may manifeſtly perceyue, for as much as we reade that Solom hadde a Soune when hee was twelue yeares of age. Therefore it is credible, that either they were equall or els not muche leſſe then oure yeres are. Alſo we read in the firſte and fourthe Booke of Ioſephus de Antiquit. Iudaic, that the Hebrevves deuiſed the yeare in Egipte before Noye his floud or the vniuerſal Catacliſme, which
yere contayned. xii monthes, & the ſame is alſo avouched by Polydor Virgilius, and Paulus Eberus late wryters. Thus haue I compendiouſly and briefely (although not preciſely collected theſe ſūdry computacions, whereunto I haue added for concluſion what the worthy Ioſephus wryteth concerning the ſame, wherin if anye thinge be through ouerſighte or otherwiſe by me myſconſtrued, I craue thy frendeſhyppe gentlye to amende it.
